Finally, each attack card is categorized as either a Quick Attack, a Combo Attack, or a Strong Attack and are resolved in that order, possibly rendering an opponent's attack inert.

At the end of the game, the kaiju with the least total damage over the course of the game is declared the winner.
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Fantasy, Fighting, Science Fiction, Video Game Theme
mechanics: Hand Management, Simultaneous Action Selection, Take That

name: Anzio: From Wildcat to Whale – 22nd January to 19th February 1944: A Campaign & Scenario Booklet for I Ain't Been Shot, Mum!
description: Covering the period of January and February 1944, this fantastic 211 page supplement by Robert Avery gives an excellent historical account of the battle as well as 21 scenarios that cover the landings right up to the close of Operation Fischfang. With complete briefings, colour maps, and victory conditions for all sides this is a superb addition to any gamers library, with scenarios for US, British and German forces.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: War Plan: Orange
description:
The global politics of the late 1920’s and early 1930’s were in a constant state of flux. The alliances of the world’s major nations seemed to change every moment. The American Armed Forces needed to devise plans for any number of possible sudden conflicts. Scenarios were written based on current equipment, technology, and strategy. The Washington treaty of 1922 that limited the tonnage of ships for the major navies never happened. The military’s solution was WAR PLAN.

War Plan: Orange was the code name given to the Navy’s scenarios dealing with a threat from Japan. Plan Orange was constantly modified as new ships, aircraft, technology, and strategies were improved. Equipment available to both sides at this time would have been fascinating to see in use, as is the focus of this game.

This will be the first of a series of “War Plan” games from Historical Board Gaming. This boxed game will come complete with all components needed to play. Fight the intense battles between the Japanese and American Navies during the early 1930’s that never were. Utilizing fantasy ships like the Lexington Class battle-cruiser as designed before it was converted to an aircraft carrier, and the Colorado class Battleship that was scrapped before building, the American forces will take on Japanese ships like the Tosa, Amagi, Kii, and No. 13 Class Battleships as well as the infamous 3-flight deck versions of Kaga and Akagi. These beautiful ships, as well as aircraft and airships, will be represented in this game with actual plastic ships, planes, and airships based on designs from pre World War II. With pieces that match the scale of other famous games in the genre, fight the Plan Orange scenarios and then add them together with other games to make your own! Never before has a War Plan Orange board game been designed like this!

HBG’s War Plan series of games will use the game engine debuted in another of HBG’s popular games, The Battle of Midway. Expanding the combat sequence to include new units, these great ships will battle for supremacy of the Pacific. The movement and combat system utilizes an area movement dynamic and D6 damage resolution. Units take turns moving based on unit type, in an attempt to out maneuver enemy units and destroy key targets for victory points.

War Plan: Black is the next planned game in HBG’s War Plan series.

Contents will include a map, Japanese and American plastic game pieces, rules, and a battle Board.

Coming in 2014
categories: Nautical, Science Fiction, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Simulation

name: Hiboria
description:
The game has its players taking turn playing a Hero (Conan, Red Sonja, Bêlit...). The rest of the players play Hero’s foes, fight a round of combat, and then the next player plays his Hero. Hence, only one player is playing a Hero at a time while the rest play his foes. If a player is playing Hero’s foes, their Hero is currently inactive and doesn’t factor into play. The Hero wins renown points by defeating his enemies. There are various victory conditions (the first player to reach 40 renown, the last player with a surviving Hero, or the last player with cards left to play wins the game).

Each player starts with one Hero card, a foe deck and a draw deck. Players randomly decide who will go first. That player becomes the active player, and places his Hero card in the center of the table and is considered to be playing the Hero. All players then draw cards form their draw deck and play begins. The Hero player then can place into play any allies and locations that he or she might have and also place items and weapons on his Hero card for use them in the upcoming combat. Whether or not cards can be placed into play depends on several factors, but the main mechanic for both foes and the Hero is their pool of prowess points. Most cards have a prowess cost that gets subtracted from this pool in order to place a card into play.

Then the foes draw from their foe deck a number of cards partly based upon how many much renown the Hero has. For every foe the Hero kills, that player places that foes card into the area known as the chronicle. Each foe has a renown score, and the total of all the felled’ foes renown score in Conan’s chronicle is his renown score.

The more defeated foes in a Hero's chronicle, the more foes the opposing player gets to put into play, i.e. the more famous the Hero gets, the more enemies want to take him down. Once the foe pool is drawn, the foe players then decide which of these foe cards they want to put into play. There are major and minor foes and rules governing how many foes from the foe draw can be put into play. Once the foes decide which of their foe cards they are able and want to play, they place their foe cards into 4 zones around the Hero(front, left, right and rear). They then place “move” cards from their draw deck for each foe they have assigned to do battle with the Hero. These cards are placed face down and represent both offensive and defensive elements. The Hero player then responds to these move cards with his own move cards, placed face up, to counter each foes’ move card. Hero’s move cards also incorporate both offensive and defensive elements. The foes then reveal their move cards and combat is resolved. If any of the foes are left alive, all players draw cards from their draw deck, and the surviving foes place new move cards onto the table. The Hero once again counters, combat is resolved, etc. until either the Hero retreats or defeats all his foes. If the Hero retreats he loses renown. If he defeats all of his foes, the Hero then can decide to rest and replenish his prowess pool and a small fraction of his life points. The Hero can also “press on.” If the Hero presses on, he starts a new round of combat, but does not get to replenish any prowess or life. Once the Hero rests or retreats, the next player then becomes the Hero.

Play continues until a victory condition is met (the first player to reach 40 renown, the last player with a surviving Conan, or the last player with cards left to play).

Each player must provide two decks which meet the appropriate requirements. The Draw Deck must contain at least 40 non-foe cards. No more than 3 copies of any given card are allowed, with no more than 1 copy of any unique card. The Foe Deck must contain at least 25 foe cards. No more than 3 copies of any given foe card (or 1 copy of any unique card) are permitted. The total renown of the foes in the Foe Deck must total from 95 to 105 points.


Hasta el momento han aparecido:

01. Set Básico
02. Brujos Resentidos
03. Velas Salvajes
04. La reina de los Yermos Helados
categories: Adventure, Card Game, Fan Expansion, Fantasy, Fighting, Mythology, Print & Play
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Player Elimination

name: ATS TT Kursk: Psel River Crossing
description:
An Advanced Tobruk System (ATS) TT expansion recreating the famous tank and infantry battles in the vicinity of the River Psel and the all important high ground of Hill 226.6 in the Soviet Union, July 1943.

Psel River Crossing utilizes the tried and true Advanced Tobruk System rules incorporating the new "TT" variant rules which feature new machine gun options, new collateral fire rules and the Advance to Contact sequence of play, among others.

This game includes new combat unit counters, scenarios, a comprehensive ATS Battlefield Walkaround and a remastered map based on the one found previously in Clash Along the Psel. Ownership of standard ATS rules, playaids and informational counters is required.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, World War II

name: THRIVE: The Board Game of Geopolitics
description:
The trusting past has led to a densely woven international trading network with the energy market at its center. Skepticism and fear have flooded the international political scene. Impending crisis has prompted world powers to escalate energy independence to a matter of national security and quick action must be taken. Not too quick though… poor decisions could drag a country to the brink of collapse. All world powers are simultaneously seeking security, and no one country’s decision ever goes without consequence. Take control, strategize, and maneuver your way to victory through a composite blend of dynamic geopolitics, economics and investment. But remember, your plan must be as innovative, versatile, and forgiving as the volatile energy market itself.

Object of the game:
The goal of the game is to completely develop your country’s oil and renewable energy resources and have 21 developments before any other player. A person's strategy must be fluid in order to adapt to the politics in play, the patents owned, and the country's resources.

Gameplay:

Each round begins with a politics card which introduces a governing rule that all players must abide by. They compound for 4 consecutive rounds and then begin again simulating a presidential cycle.

Also at the beginning of each round a patent card is auctioned off. Patents give players ownership of specific technologies that will increase their profits or allow them to develop at a faster rate.

Play proceeds with individual turns. Each player begins his/her turn by rolling 2 dice which determines if the price of an energy development increases or decreases. A disaster can also occur which destroys the player's most developed land plot.

Once the price is set, that player can either purchase developments, pay back debt, invade another country, or take no action and save his her money. Each turn ends by collecting profits ($100 per domestic development unless patent says otherwise).

The first player to build all 21 energy developments on their country and pay off all debt wins the game!
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Pattern Building, Simulation, Tile Placement, Trading

name: Weltflug: Spiel
description:
On the cover written: "Weltflug - Spiel. Auf dem Luftwege rund um die Erde. Das neuzeitliche Gesellschaftsspiel von Walter Mackenthun". The board game published by Edler & Krische in Hannover 1925.
Typical roll and move board game with 100 stops. The first player, who cross 100 squares, wins the game.
Game board is made with many printed aerial photography, which made by Walter Mackenthun (17/08/1882;†1948)- aviation pioneer and one of the first pilot with license in Germany, pilot squadron leader in World War I.

name: Great War Spearhead II
description:
Divisional and Corps level rules for refighting the big battles from 1900 to 1920. Primarily focused on World War One, Great War Spearhead II can be used from Russo-Japanese War, 2nd Balkan War and Russian Civil War.

Great War Spearhead II is a stand alone set of miniature rules and is a step forward from the original Great War Spearhead. It encompasses some new rules, new TO&E for Russo-Japanese War and three new scenarios.
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War I

name: Cyber War
description:
General description:
Cyber War is a card strategy game played on a game board divided into squares. Set in the style of the classic spaceship videogames, the players should use their resources wisely, launch coordinated attacks and defend their bases for the win. The objetive of the game is to capture the enemy bases while avoiding the opponent take ours.
During the game we’ll control an army of robots, ships and defense towers created in automated factories located somewhere in the cyberspace, where an endless war takes place between information nodes, adopting the form of small pixelated war constructs of only a few bytes of information. A relentless war takes place in the digital space, perhaps in your own computer, in your phone or inside the ADSL wiring of your home.

Players: 2 or 4.
Recommended age: 12 years and up.
Game length: 40-90 minutes.

Game components:
- Game board.
- 180 cards, including 4 different game sets (blue, green, red and yellow), each one including a 32 cards Playing deck and 6 Base cards, and 15 Terain cards.
- 2 combat dice.
- 70 tokens.
- Rule booklet.
mechanics: Action Points, Grid Movement, Player Elimination, Rock-Paper-Scissors, Secret Unit Deployment, Team-Based Game

name: Warlords & Sellswords
description:
Warlords and Sellswords is card game about building an army to impress the local king so that he will hire your army to fight his war. You will compete against other new armies over a ten round game. The king has outlawed open combat between all armies applying for the job but, what the king does not know will not hurt him. You can murder, steal, and sabotage the other armies to make yours look the most appealing for war. The king will make his decision at the end of 10th day but everyday leading up to it he will send an advisor to form an option of the each army.

Players will spend 10 rounds, in 4 phases. The Draw phase, the Action phase, the Cleanup phase and the Evaluation phase form a single round. During play, players will build an army, by spending resources and hiring troops from their hand. Players do not manage a personal deck, instead they build their own personal army to gain points and disrupt other players.

At the end of each round the player with the most points receives a recommendation from the King's advisors. The winner is the player after ten rounds with the most power in their army, and the most reccomendations.

name: Reviravolta
description:
To win this race anything is justified!
Change the race track surface, change the weather condition, throw obstacles in the path of your opponents. Even change car parts or the driver!

Board game for all ages, created during SPJam 2013

Game Play:
"'ReviraVolta' {'Turnaround'} is a racing game using cards. These cards are used to represent your car and driver during the race; the condition of the track and the weather, obstacles, and special events. Initially your car and driver are represented by 3 cards drawn at random, composing the driver, the car body, and the car's method of locomotion. You have a hand of five cards at your disposal. The first player to complete a lap of the race track is the winner.

Each turn you have a chance to take an action and then move your car, or you can move your car and then act. The distance your car moves depends on the interaction between the parts of your car, and the prevailing condition of the track and the weather.

As an action you can play a card from your hand to replace parts of your car or driver to improve the distance your car moves. You can also play a card to replace the prevailing conditions, possibly increasing your car movement, or adversly effecting the movement of the other players. There are also obstacle cards to slow down another player. 'Revira volta' cards swap the driver or parts of the car amongst all the players. At the end of your turn you draw cards to return to a hand of 5.

Use your action wisely because in Revira Volta the winner is the player who can overcome obstacles, and use the weather variations and changes to the race track to their best advantage!"


Pra vencer essa corrida vale tudo: trocar o terreno da pista, as condições do clima, colocar obstáculos na frente dos oponentes, e até mesmo trocar o seu carro ou o piloto !!!

Jogo de tabuleiro para todas as idades, criado durante o SPJam 2013.

O Jogo:
"Em Reviravolta, todos começam com um carro e cinco cartas na mão. Durante seu turno o jogador deve usar uma carta e comprar uma para repor a mão.

Com esta carta ele pode mudar o clima, o terreno, uma parte de seu carro ou até atrapalhar o adversário.
Use com inteligência, para ganhar vantagens ou atrapalhar os outros competidores.

Em Reviravolta vence aquele que for mais rápido e perspicaz, ultrapassar obstáculos, variações climáticas e mudanças de terreno.
"
categories: Humor, Party Game, Print & Play, Racing

name: 30 Days of Night: A Game of Survival
description: 30 Days of Night: A Game of Survival is based on the 30 Days of Night comic book series from Steve Niles and Ben Templesmith. No details have been announced about the gameplay.

name: Clique Mystique
description: Clique Mystique is a tile-laying card game for two players, using the Mystique Deck. The object is to own the most cards at the end of the game. Play starts from a randomly dealt 3x3 array of cards and gradually expands into a 7x7 virtual board. Players form groups of closely related cards (Cliques) or completely unrelated cards (Motley Crews), capturing opposing stacks in the process.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Pattern Building, Tile Placement

name: Construction Site
description:
In Construction Site, you and your friends are builders. You have received the plans for the buildings you will construct and you have ordered the materials you will need to build. However, there has been a mix-up. Instead of receiving the materials you asked for, you get random shipments delivered at regular intervals. You and your fellow builders must team up to sort through the mess, selling what materials you can to pay for the materials you need before time runs out!

One to four players must follow Blueprint cards and play Material cards to build the structures on the Blueprints before the deck runs out.

Players have to "pay" for any Materials that they play by discarding other cards from their hands or removing cards from the Material deck. When a Blueprint is completed, players earn a reward, which is to return some cards from the discard pile to the Material deck.

Construction Site fits in a small box that fits in your pocket, containing all necessary components to play.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Set Collection

name: Mano draugai
description:
The aim of Mano draugai is to gather your group of friends by collecting cards with points. In the game characters from books of Kęstutis Kasparavičius are used.

The game contains:
- 15 large cards with 3, 4 or 5 characters on each;
- 35 small cards with 1 character on each;
- 21 small cards with a pair of characters on each;
- 6 small "almighty" cards;
- rule booklet.

In the game each player is dealt six small cards and three large cards are uncovered for everyone to see. Players in turn play one small card bellow the big card. All the characters displayed on the small card must match the ones displayed on the large card and must not be matched by other small cards, that have already been played bellow the large card. The "almighty" card can be played bellow any large card and matches any one character. The player, who matches the last character on the large card, takes it and scores the points displayed on the card. The game is played until all 15 large cards are claimed.
categories: Animals, Card Game, Children's Game, Novel-based

name: Asteroid Miner
description:
Be the CEO of one of five corporations competing to set up mining operations in the asteroid belt. Demands for resources are at a record high. Corporations, fueled by their desire for wealth and power, race for the chance to be the supplier of these resources. In seven years, the rest of Earth's corporations will have caught up and the ridiculous prices for these precious materials will start to drop. Be the corporation that profits the most and show the galaxy who is the best.

Asteroid Miner is a worker placement and resource management board game in which players are the CEO of one of the first corporations to make mining the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter profitable. Players play for a maximum of six rounds, which represent a year in space. Each round, players must pick a special subcontractor card which gives special powers for the rest of the round. During the round players must choose where to send their crews: mine, blast, upgrade, or pick up contracts.

name: Hei Su Hong Su
description:
Hei Su Hong Su is a battle of wits between two opponents, played on an elegantly crafted board framed in genuine cherry or mahogany. Each game includes an authentic Chinese i-ching coin. In Hei Su Hong Su, when tokens are moved off one end of the board, they return on the opposite side. Additionally, unlike other popular strategy games, players are permitted to move neutral and their opponent’s tokens as their own. Hei Su Hong Su is truly a unique and intriguing strategy game.

In Hei Su Hong Su, one player is red, other is black. At the start of the game, each player has nine pieces set up in a square in opposite corners on the board, with 18 white pieces occupying the other two corners. Players take turns “sliding” rows or columns of pieces by removing a piece from an edge and adding it to the other edge. If a player traps a piece by surrounding it with 4 of his color (including “wrapping around” to the other side of the board), it is replaced with with one of that player's pieces. If a player captures and replaces a white piece, the “tug of war” marker moves 1 in his favor on the scale. If a player captures and replaces an opponent’s piece, the marker moves 2 in his favor on the scale. The game ends when the marker has moved all the way to the end of the scale; that player is the winner.

name: NoGo
description:
IntroductionNoGo is a combinatorial game for two players: Black and White. It's played on the intersections (points) of an initially empty square or rectangular board. Board sizes bigger than 9x9 are not recommended. 6x7 boards have been used in some human matches.

NoGo takes the Go concepts of group and liberty and uses them in the most minimalistic possible way. The resulting game, with no captures, no cycles and no scoring, is no rival for Go, but remains a fertile ground for tactical challenges in the Dots and Boxes style.

This game seems to have been first mentioned by someone called John Moore at Sensei's Library, in April 1, 2005.



DefinitionsA group is a set of orthogonally adjacent, like-colored stones.

A liberty of a group is an empty point orthogonally adjacent to that group.



PlayBlack plays first, then turns alternate. On his turn, a player must place a stone of his color on an empty point of the board. At the end of a turn, all groups on the board (both friendly and enemy) must have at least one liberty. Otherwise the player's move is illegal. Whoever can't make a move on his turn loses.

name: Heroes of Ismia
description:
Fight monsters, gather materials and go on quests to gain power in this new customizable resource management RPG board game.

Ismia is in peril once again!

Click Play Die Games presents Heroes of Ismia, a new fantasy adventure resource management RPG board game. Players take on the roles of highly customizable Heroes, each with unique powers and endgame conditions, creating dynamic gameplay with high replay-ability.

Twenty years have passed since the great Demon Siege nearly brought the city to its knees. Now new dangers have emerged that threaten to destroy Ismia once and for all! A dragon has awoken in the Daggerspine Mountains, and is sating her terrible hunger on the villages of the north. A necromancer has risen a dark tower in Nara, to the east, and a scourge of the walking dead now plague the countryside. Amidst all this, rumors swirl that the Usurper King is once again rallying the forces of Anmarch to destroy the city of Ismia once and for all!

Ismia is in need of Heroes once again.
mechanics: Area Movement, Commodity Speculation, Dice Rolling, Role Playing, Variable Player Powers

name: The Fungus Kingdom
description:
In The Fungus Kingdom, you search for mushrooms in forests and other dark places, then sell them in the kingdom's marketplace and to itinerant traders who appear periodically. With the assistance of various "masters", you could become the most successful collector/dealer, thereby obtaining the most money possible through your sales — and thus the most victory points (VPs). Of course to do this you must fight for the best seats with trade partners and ensure good relations with them.

Each player starts the game with an individual player board, six workers, six gold, and a mushroom card. By placing the appropriate number of workers on the various action spaces, you can purchase mushroom, land or water; buy or implement demand or master cards; purchase new warehouses or assistants; and produce or sell mushrooms. Players can hold five cards in hand from one round to the next, and after nine rounds players tally their VPs to see who wins.

name: Ray Gun Roulette
description:
Disintegrate your friends!

Ray Gun Roulette is a high tech, high stakes game of bluffing for 2 to 10 players. Players are participating in this deadly game to acquire as many crystals as they can. Choose from an assortment of highly illegal firearms and blast away until you're either the last player alive or you possess all the crystals!

Each player starts with two primary shields (blue gems) and three crystals (the currency of the game). If a player runs out of crystals they have lost the game. A primary shield can absorb one blast from one of these lethal firearms, if a player gets hit with just one of these weapons unshielded, they will get disintegrated, and lose the game. The weapon cards contain all the information needed to use them.

Each weapon, in addition to the illustration and weapon name, have a number of features,
-Kill-o-watt rating: the power rating of the weapon, if both players are targeting each other, the higher kill-o-watt weapon wins and damages their target.
-Deflector shield rating: some weapons have a built-in deflector shield. It can deflect a shot coming from a player that you are not targeting this round. If the kill-o-watt rating is less than or equal to the deflector shield rating (remember to multiply the deflector rating by 1,000 before comparing) the shot has no effect. Otherwise the shot goes through and can be absorbed by a primary shield or disintegrate the player.
-Special ability: each weapon has a unique special ability. Some of these can be particularly game-changing and devastating. Any player may negate the special ability of a weapon at the cost of one crystal (thrown into the pot for the current round), once per round, immediately after the effect would have taken place.

A round of Ray Gun Roulette has a number of phases,
-Choose weapons, dealer deals each player 3 cards, they choose one and discard the rest.
-Ante up!, each player places a crystal in the pot.
-Aim, players pick a target, making a "gun" hand pointing at them. This stage is when the bluffing really takes place, feel free to switch targets, intimidate, trash talk, and fold at any time.
-Last chance, Dealer declares "Last chance to fold, targets locked!". From this point on players cannot switch targets. Players may not fold once this phase has ended.
Fire!, all together players call out "3, 2, 1, FIRE!" and flip over their cards, revealing what weapons they were using.
-Determine winners, Determining the winner is simple; if you lost a primary shield this round or were disintegrated, you lost. Otherwise the player has won and will split the pot with the other winners. crystals that cannot be split evenly between the winners remain in the pot for the next round.
-Play continues until either one player has all the crystals or is the only one alive.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Party Game, Science Fiction
mechanics: Player Elimination, Push Your Luck, Variable Player Powers

name: Tabula Pasta
description:
The chef that makes the most dishes wins!

Tabula Pasta is a game where the players are all chefs working at a small Italian restaurant. They are trying to out do each other by getting the most satisfied customers. Each customer's order is determined by rolling three special dice (meat, pasta, and sauce). The chefs must race against each other to fulfil the orders using the cards in their hand, the deck, and the pantry. The chef with the most satisfied customers by the end of the game is the winner!

The board game is a table, set for four persons. To begin the game you place a meeple (patron) in each chair. Determine each patron's order by rolling their own set of special dice, one each of a sauce, meat, and pasta die. The players (chefs) then have to match the patron's order by drawing cards from the grocery delivery (deck) or the pantry (three piles of discarded cards, shared by everyone, that haven't been used to fill an order). Once an order has been filled the player shows everyone their match, moves the patron next to them to keep score, places the used cards in the bus bin (discard pile, you can never dig from the trash to complete an order, that's gross!), and finally seats a new patron (if any are left) and rolls a new order for them. Play continues until everyone has been served.

In addition to the six types of pasta, meat, and sauce cards there are also wild cards and secret ingredient cards (a pasta, meat, or sauce that counts as any other type, but you can only use one to fill an order). There are variations for faster games: using less patrons and/or removing the meat cards and dice (light lunch).
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Set Collection

name: A Wargamer's Guide to The First Crusade 1097-1099AD
description:
A booklet on campaigns and battles of the medieval period, from the 5th to 15th centuries, intended to give an up to date historical account of the events and provide a beginner's guide to wargaming those events

Includes:

Concise, footnoted, historical narrative of the campaign, including sections on personalities, troops, armaments and strategic movements.
Accounts the battles of Dorylaeum, Antioch, and Ascalon, fully describing from contemporary and archaeological sources.
Chapters on wargaming the campaign and the three battles using available commercial board games and miniature rules, including appropriate army lists.
Simple painting guide


Softback; 55 pages.

name: Dust Tactics: "Snow Lynx"
description:
We are very proud to introduce our third Elite Exclusive item: Sigrid and her own walker the Snow Lynx, which she used in Zverograd at the beginning of 1947. Sigrid, who has the soul of a huntress, is a formidable walker pilot. She was one of the very first of these on the planet, since the first prototype of the Luther was created. Now she hunts her preys amidst the ruins of Zverograd.

As you can see this “Elite Version” comes with a special diorama base that can also serve as a playing base for the Snow Lynx. It takes a little bit more than one space on the battlefield, but consider it as one space. The walker can also be placed on a regular grey round base that we have magnetized: you can swap the Snow Lynx from one base to another with ease.
We also magnetized Sigrid: she can be played independently, the rock under her feet is the same size as a regular base. And thanks to the magnet she can be placed back on the large base with her walker instantly. In an instant Sigrid and the Snow Lynx can go from a Collector Item to being fully playable. And of course, as usual, everything is already painted and you can enjoy it as soon as you open the box.

This brand new JagdLuther model has a “belly” machine gun, that can be used with deadly effects against any infantry.

Of course these two models come with their very own unit cards, and are fully playable in Dust Tactics and Dust Warfare.
categories: Miniatures, Science Fiction, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: Collie of Duty
description:
You are a border collie trying to herd as many sheep as you can from the pasture into your pen, but your opponents have the same goal. Whenever the pasture (Sheep deck) is empty, the game is over and whoever has the most sheep in their pen is the winner.

On your turn, you will draw a card from the duty deck, and then you will perform two actions. Those actions are A) drawing a card from the duty deck B) playing a card from your hand or C) herding a sheep aka taking the top card from the sheep deck and putting it in your pasture.

Some of the sheep cards are rare sheep such as the Ninja Sheep, the Fat Sheep, the Buff Sheep, or the Goat. Each special sheep has a special ability printed on the card. Most of the sheep in the sheep deck are normal mundane sheep, however.

In the 30 min game some of the cards you will draw (duty cards) will help you herd more sheep or perform more actions, but many of the duty cards are harmful to your opponents, such as sending feral corgis to kidnap their sheep or even worse, infecting an opponent with rabies.

name: Kill Code
description:
Somewhere out in space, a military research station was recently damaged by a storm. While the damage and debris could be repaired, to the researchers' horror a retired military weapon residing in storage, an armored drone programmed only for wiping out a population, was reactivated by a malfunction and began to brutally slaughter them one by one.

As the team of surviving scientists, brave and explore the hallways of the facility, avoid the drone, and lead the survivor bearing the drone's "Kill Code" device to the terminal in order to begin the deactivation process and survive until repair crews can reach the station. As the drone, figure out which of the survivors is carrying the Kill Code device, then viciously hunt them down...
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Pick-up and Deliver, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Unlikely Heroes
description:
You are a citizen of the town of Bastion. Your town guard have been slain by barbarians. And now they are coming for you. Your job is to defend your town. You are no great warrior. You are no mighty soldier. You are just a normal citizen. But you are also Bastion's only hope.

The Last Bastion is a competitive game for 1-4 players. You goal is to train enough with the village elders to be able to save your town, then go out and defeat the barbarian horde. Train too much and the horde will overrun the town. Train too little and you will be trampled. Will you be the hero of Bastion, or it's martyr.

name: The Grand Tour: A Racing Adventure Game
description:
An entry level bicycle racing game with dice rolling being the first stage in movement with a small hand of cards available to adjust the final movement total each turn. Use of the cards adds some of the color of racing and can be a major factor in the flow of the race.

The race has three stages including a time trial on a two sided board. The first and third stages are started at opposite ends of one side of the board and the time trial uses the second side. Points are earned at sprint lines and at the finish of each stage. Wind, pothole and water puddle spaces provide obstacles to the riders.

The game includes the double sided board, 6 rider miniatures, 120 Grand Tour Cards, 30 Feed Zone cards, 2 D-6, a pencil, notepad and the instructions.

name: Railway Rivals Map LW: London and Western
description: This is an expansion map of London and the South West for Railway Rivals and Dampfross. The base game involves route building and the second part of the games involves racing along player routes between cities to win prize money. The player with the most money at the end of the game wins. Based on an original design by Erik Fudge.

name: Railway Rivals Map ND: North Germany
description: This is an expansion map of Northern Germany for Railway Rivals and Dampfross which involves players first building track and then players may race between cities. The base game involves route building and the second part of the games involves racing along player routes between cities to win prize money. The player with the most money at the end of the game wins.

name: Mystique Guilds
description:
Mystique Guilds is a 2 to 4 player game for The Mystique Deck derived from Nestortiles Duel, by the same designer. You need one Mystique Deck to play the game.
In Mystique Guilds, the combination of suit+colour is called ‘guild’. So there are 12 guilds (3 colours times 4 suits). Your goal is to control the most guilds when the game ends.

Shuffle the whole deck and place it facing down in the middle of the table. This is the Draw Deck. Next to it a (now inexistent) Discard Deck will be created.

Determine the starting player by any peaceful means. Players take turns in anticlockwise order during the game until the endgame condition is reached.

On their turn, players must do only one of these 2 actions:

- Pick one card from the Draw Deck or the Discard Deck.

- Buy cards.

How to buy cards:

1. Place one of your cards facing up before you. This is the Influence Card.

2. Draw up to as many cards from the Draw Deck as the number on your Influence Card.

3. Place the Influence Card facing up on the Discard Deck.

If, at any moment, the Draw Deck gets exhausted, the game ends.

Each player adds up the values of each guild on their hand. The player with the highest value for each guild controls that guild and scores a point (tip: score the 12 guilds in order for clarity). In case of two or more players having the same value for a guild, none of them scores for it. The guild of blue suns is an exception and scores two points. So there are 13 available points in total.

Ties for the first place are broken by the lowest number of cards. If a tie persists then play again.

Variants:

Variant 1: Cards can be bought from both decks.

Variant 2 (the Market): You can buy cards from another player. Both players must agree on the cards being exchanged. The Influence card is given to that player instead of discarding it.
mechanics: Commodity Speculation, Memory, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: Captain's Log #3
description:
Excerpt from the back:

This issue of Captain's Log includes the following exciting features:

The First Round, an exciting science fiction story by Stephen Kacarides. A related scenario is included and may be played by four players.

The Life and Times of Deth O'Kay, a special group of scenarios.

Ground Combat is portrayed in a stylized set of game rules. Several scenarios are provided.

Major Fleet Battles are presented in the scenarios Titan and the Unicorn and A Time to Live; A Time to Die.

Over Twenty New Scenarios are presented in this issue.
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game
publishers: Amarillo Design Bureau, Inc., Task Force Games

name: Captain's Log #29
description:
featuring "Birth of a Feud!" A new short story about Gorns and Romulans with accompanying scenario titled.."A Mission of Vital Importance".

New Ships including,Tholian Dreadnoughts makeovers..

Database,Battle group assault the Holdfast,Dek plans of the Federation Express,Hydran vs Lyran "Brothers of the Anarchist"..

Scenario's include.,Klingon D3's find the Romlans SITTING BIRDS,Gorn and Romulan ships find ONE CORNER OF HELL,

F&E Fans will find new rules and rulings, their own Proposals Board and Why articles, the Ship Information Table for the new ships, and lots of tactics.
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Advanced Tobruk System Basic Game II: Action at Carentan
description:
ATS BASIC GAME II continues to Carentan with an all-new 2-piece board! The module adds a set of scenarios + a BG II rulebook and play aids! You can dive right in and begin experiencing the battle while mastering the system. The map is not printed on paper, and instead consists of TWO 12" × 18" BOARDS you are sure to enjoy! What's more, the presentation allows you to use your existing ATS counters from your collection for a low cost battle experience.

An Expansion for ATS. First released edition does NOT include counters needed for play. Counters needed from a previous game with American/German units, or available direct from Critical Hit.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: ATS Basic Game II: Busting the Bocage – Rangers
description:
ATS BASIC GAME II is back and brings you into the heart of Normandy's bocage country in this new edition that remasters the D-Day Rangers map terrain and adds a set of scenarios + a BG II rulebook and play aids! You can dive right in and begin mastering the system right away. The map is not printed on paper, and instead consists of TWO 12" × 18" BOARDS you are sure to enjoy! What's more, the presentation allows you to use your existing ATS counters from the collection for a low cost battle experience.

An Expansion for ATS. First released edition does NOT include counters needed for play. Counters needed from a previous game with American/German units, or available direct from Critical Hit.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Hexagon Grid, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Flintlock and Ramrod
description:
Skirmishes in the era of the muzzleloading musket.

With these rules you can refight skirmishes in all the major conflicts which were dominated by the Brown Bess and decided by the bayonet – from the end of the 17th Century to the middle of the 18th Century.
categories: American Indian Wars, American Revolutionary War, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Superpowerful Bonanza
description:
Superpowerful Bonanza is a handmade cardboard/spruce-wood multilevel three-dimensional board game developed by You Tube's Homemade Game Guru. The game features a new line of comic book superheroes competing to save their city from five super villain bosses. Each hero character has an origin story and mission to complete (explained in an accompanying one-shot comic book). The game play was inspired by classic side-scrolling video games like Double Dragon and Contra.

Each hero and villain has a main game card that lists their 1)strength, 2)speed and 3)intelligence points. Each hero must add to their strength, speed and intelligence points by collecting cards based on weapons, health, powers and superpowers. Cards are collected by moving along playing spaces in each level. Game cards accumulated not only provide point levels for strength, speed and intelligence, but they also give specific instructions on their limitations and extra abilities. Some cards can be kept and others are one-time use.

Players compete to gain as many points as possible before taking on each level's villainous boss. Each boss has a complete deck of cards to fuel their strength, speed and intelligence points. Once a boss is reached, a player must duel card-to-card and hope they have the right combination of points to win. Even before players reach the level boss, they must combat minor enemies and deal with civilians (which can help or hinder the mission). Each of the 5 levels plays slightly different from the rest.
categories: Adventure, Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Video Game Theme
mechanics: Area Movement, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Variable Player Powers

name: Roman Glory II: ATS
description:
This revised expansion for Advanced Tobruk System (ATS) enables players to recreate the fighting between the Italian CSIR and Soviet forces in and around the village of Nikitovka, Nov. 1941.

This edition contains revised scenarios, Italian personnel and vehicle counters and a "winterized" 12x18" cardstock map depicting the Nikitovka area.

This expansion revises the previously released Nikitovka 1941.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Line of Sight, Simulation

name: Woo-Wee!
description: WooWee is hands down the handsiest game around! This game of crazy hand gestures has all players playing simultaneously, attempting to get rid of all the cards in their deck. Each card has a saying [that needs to be said] and a gesture [that needs to be gested]. If your card doesn't match anyone else's, then your card goes to the center of the table. BUT, if your card does match another's, then you both must race to complete all the cards in the center of the table before you slap the BAM! card. Be the last to slap the BAM! and you get to add all the cards to your deck.

name: Stalingrad Solitaire: Death Knell of the German 6th Army 1942
description: This page does not exist. You can edit this page to create it.

name: Super Sunday Football
description: American Football game that uses bits of film to show the outcome of chosen plays. Each player uses a playbook, one for defense and one for the offence. Plays are chosen and the apt piece of film shows the outcome.

name: Infernis
description:
A board game without dice, based in risk control and strategy. With a duration of 30-60 min, in “Infernis” 2 to 4 players take the role of as many witches challenging each other in a cruel game of magic and cunning.

Essentially, it consists in a large square plain with parcels that contain magic and form a grid. When this magic is activated, an arcane wind blows the occupant following different directions and with variable strength (and, subsequently, range). These blows, along with the witch-players’ ability to control or anticipate them, will determine whether the peasants stay on the island long enough or they are thrown into the deadly flames.

Only the witch that manages to keep her unlucky peasants alive will win, preventing them from falling in the eternal flames that surround the cursed island of Infernis.

name: Nördlingen 1634: Habsburg High Water Mark
description:
This is the first Self-Published version of the game using Ben Hull's "Musket and Pike Battle System". It was the DTP precursor to Sweden Fights On. It contains the Nordlingen Battle only.

---

Though the Swedes struggled with command after the death of King Gustav II Adolf, they continued to exploit the momentum he had generated. A strong Swedish force pushed into Bavaria under the joint command of Duke Bernhard and Field Marshal Horn. The Habsburgs effected a union of forces with their Spanish cousins at Nördlingen, besieging the Protestant stronghold. The Swedes were drawn into a trap.

name: Mystique Domination
description:
Mystique Domination is a partnership climbing game for The Mystique Deck. Legal patterns always consist of a single color of cards, and suits are irrelevant. With those considerations, the legal patterns are:

n-of-a-kind
numerical sequence of any length


Thus, a single card is actually both pattern types, and thus can be followed by either pattern, and can follow either pattern; this means it can also allow the pattern to change mid-trick.

In order follow the pattern that is led, it must be the same pattern, same color, and have a higher total value. Once everyone passes, the person who last played wins the trick, and collects her last play, and all cards on the play pile that match any of the suits in that last play.

Points are awarded based on having a majority of cards in a suit, and by having the majority of cards overall. Once a team reaches 100 points, the team with the higher score wins.

name: Mystique Circle
description:
Mystique Circle is a trick-taking game for The Mystique Deck, in which the suits are ranked in a rock-paper-scissors-esque cycle: Suns > Moons > Crowns > Arms > Suns, and face value (1–5) breaks ties; all colors are equal, but you must follow the color led when playing.

Each hand, you set aside three cards face-down as a bid for how many tricks you think you will win.

The trick winner is reevaluated with each card played into the trick, which means that in a five-player game, it's possible to go full-circle through the entire suit cycle, such that the fifth player wins the trick with a lower number of the same suit that was led.

At the end of the hand, earn 1 point for each trick you took + 20 points if that number equals your bid. Once a player reaches 60 points, the player with the highest score wins.

name: Chain of Restraints
description:
Chain of Restraints is a game for The Mystique Deck, in which 2–4 players compete to create 4-in-a-row of a single aspect type (e.g. four reds, or four crowns, or four 4s) on a floating 4×4 grid.

The card you play constrains the next player's play, which is not allowed to match your card's number, color, or suit.

The game ends if someone completes a 4-in-a-row to win, or if the deck runs out, ending the game in a draw: Play again to determine a winner.

name: Mystical Eddies
description:
Mystical Eddies is a trick-taking game for The Mystique Deck, in which the player who leads the trick must assume she won't win the trick, because a subsequent player determines the context of the card she leads.

The game can be played either for a fixed number of rounds, or to a target score.

When leading a trick, you can play any card you like; however, because the Mystique cards have three aspects (suit, number, color), the next player chooses which aspect to follow. Everyone else in the trick must follow the same aspect (or toss a card if unable, like most trick-taking games). If the second player's card followed two aspects, then the other players must follow both.

This game uses the following ranking:

suit: suns > moons > arms > crowns
number: 5 > 4 > 3 > 2 > 1
color: yellow > red > blue


The trick winner is determined as follows:

Following suit: Highest number; tie goes to highest color.
Following color: Highest suit; tie goes to highest number.
Following number: Highest color; tie goes to highest suit.
Following suit and color: Highest number.
Following suit and number: Highest color.
Following color and number: Highest suit.


Should no one be able to follow a led card, the trick leader wins the trick.

Each trick won is worth 1 point.

Advanced Scoring Variant: Balance
Each player earns points in three categories:

Tricks won following suit.
Tricks won following color.
Tricks won following number.


When a player wins a trick, she earns one point in the appropriate category. If she won a trick that followed two aspects, she earns one point in each of those two categories! Your category with the lowest score is what counts toward winning.

name: The Hoarder and the Gatekeeper
description:
The Hoarder and the Gatekeeper is a combinatorial game for 2 players that was published on issue 19 of Bitcoin Magazine and also on the Bitcoin Magazine website:

http://bitcoinmagazine.com/12324/gatekeepers/

The Hoarder and the Gatekeeper is a game for 2 players (the Hoarder and the Gatekeeper) that can be played on a hexagonal grid of any size (recommended 4 hexes per side. We’ll call it 'Coinland'.

'Coinland' is full of coins, one coin per cell with the exception of the central one. Each cell is connected to its neighbouring cells by an edge. The 'Hoarder' will try to collect as many coins as possible by moving from cell to cell, while the 'Gatekeeper' will try to collect coins by ‘taxing’ the Hoarder, placing gates on the edges between cells and charging a fee each time the Hoarder crosses them.

Use loose change or draughts pieces or beans or whatever to fill the cells. Keep the centre cell empty.

The Hoarder uses a chess pawn (or any other object that fits inside a cell). The Gatekeeper uses a marker of a different colour than the edges of the board (if possible). Place the Hoarder piece in the centre cell.

Starting with the Gatekeeper, players alternate turns during the game until all coins have been collected or the Hoarder is not able to move, whatever happens first.

On her turn, the Gatekeeper must draw a gate in any edge between 2 cells.

And on her turn, the Hoarder must move her piece in a straight line to a non-empty cell (it must contain a coin) as many spaces as she wishes in any of the 6 directions. She must pay as many coins to the Gatekeeper as gates she crossed during the move (she cannot move if she doesn’t have coins enough to pay). Hoarder collects the coin that is on the destination cell. Moving is mandatory if possible. The hoarder can declare the end of the game after her turn.

When the game ends, count the coins that the Hoarder has managed to keep. This is her score. Then reverse roles and play again. Whoever achieved the highest score playing as the Hoarder wins.

name: The Horus Heresy: Book Three – Extermination
description:
The third and final part of the Isstvan trilogy, this book details the aftermath of the Dropsite Massacre on Istvaan V, and two other major battles fought between the Loyalist and Traitor Legions as the Horus Heresy swept out from the Isstvan system and into the wider Imperium of Mankind: the Battle of Phall and the Invasion of Paramar.

Also featured are the background and game rules for the units, characters and vehicles of the four Legions covered in this book: the Alpha Legion, Imperial Fists, Raven Guard and Iron Warriors, and a Mechanicum army list, as well as new campaigns and missions.

The book itself is a full colour 285 page hardback, leather bound with metal corner clasps, foil-edged pages and embossed and silvered text.
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Grad Wars
description:
In Grad Wars all players are students in different Universities. Their aim is to get their degree before everyone else does by passing 20 lessons first. They do this either by studying hard, or by visiting the other players in their classroom and harassing them.

Players can pass up to 5 lessons in every turn. They get their grade by rolling a 10-sided die for every lesson and then modifying the die with cards thrown by themselves or other players.

Cards can be adding or subtracting from a grade, and they can be special cards. But basically they describe student life as it is, or rather as we think it is. Players drink tons of coffee, they get shut in in bunkers to study focused, and they give exams using a Divine Pen. They also invade other players’ homes to sabotage their alarm clock, and they cause a Zombie Apocalypse inside other players’ classrooms. And they start crying in front of professors to get a passing grade, they cheat like there is no tomorrow, and they go to parties that cause year-long hangovers. Grad Wars is a game for the students who want to get their degree first no matter what the cost, or the means.

Στο παιχνίδι αυτό ο παίχτης είναι φοιτητές σε διαφορετικές σχολές. Σκοπός του παιχνιδιού είναι να πάρει πτυχίο πριν από τους υπόλοιπους, συμπληρώνοντας 20 περασμένα μαθήματα. Αυτό γίνεται είτε με το να κάτσει να διαβάσει, ή με το να πηγαίνει στη σχολή του άλλου και να τον παρενοχλεί. Σε κάθε γύρο μπορεί να δώσει μέχρι 5 μαθήματα, και οι γύροι συνεχίζονται μέχρι να βγει κάποιος νικητής.

Οι κάρτες περιγράφουν τη φοιτητική ζωή έτσι όπως είναι, ή μάλλον έτσι όπως πιστεύουμε ότι είναι. Ο παίχτης πίνει τόνους καφέ, κλείνεται σε πυρηνικά καταφύγια για να διαβάσει πιο συγκεντρωμένος, γράφει εξετάσεις με το Στυλό των Θεών. Μπαίνει στο σπίτι του άλλου και του σαμποτάρει το ξυπνητήρι, κλείνει γρίπη σε ένα βαζάκι και το βάζει κάτω από μύτες, στέλνει Ζόμπι Συμφοιτητές στο αμφιθέατρο των συμπαικτών του. Κλαίγεται στους καθηγητές για να περάσει, αντιγράφει μέχρι τελικής πτώσης, πηγαίνει σε πάρτι που το χανγκόβερ κρατάει ένα χρόνο. Ο Πτυχιούχος είναι το παιχνίδι του Φυτού, του φοιτητή που πρέπει να πάρει πτυχίο πρώτος με καθε μέσο.

name: Buildingue
description:
Two players confront one another to construct the least high tower with 3D polyominoes.

Both players have a gameboard 3x3. In the center of the table, there are 29 3D polyominoes. Initially, each player chooses a polyomino. When both players have chosen a polyomino, they exchange. Everyone must now place the piece on his board. A polyomino must not exceed the gameboard. Then everyone chooses a new polyomino.

When each player has placed 14 polyominoes, the game is over. The player whose tower is less high wins.

name: Starbattles Center Ion Cathode Ships (Codex)
description:
Center Ion Cathode Ships
2nd Expansion Race Pack for Starbattles
24 New Control Sheet Diagrams
6 Page Booklet
This set introduces a 2nd new race for the Starbattle game system.

Using centralized engines this race (referred to as CODEX)brings new effects and special rules to the game.
Booklet includes all instances where the CODEX ships differ from existing ships.

Also included is a construction notes and charts showing tech levels and build information for the 24 ship and craft types available to a CODEX player so they can be integrated in one off or campaign games

Also included is an encounter chart for determining random opposing forces. This chart includes fleet types form the original game and it\'s supplement as well as all three expansion sets.

The Control Sheet Diagrams like previous sets are meant for photocopying and only have the shields, armor and engines established. This leaves the player to determine the internal makeup and armament of each ship allowing for a very customizable game experience.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: I Sumeri di Ur, Uruk, Nippur e Lagash
description:
This game is for pupils aged 8-9 years, studing the Mesopotamic Sumerian Civilization.

Farm your land, harvest your grain, build your city, commerce with your neighbours... it gives a taste of how the Mesopotamian agricolture and first cities worked.

Each player is the king of one of the Sumerian cities of the title; in every seasonal turn, the king must choose which building to build in its city, each building is represented by the tiles taken at the start of each turn. The king must carefully plan how to increase its city, in order to get enough food for each building; in case of famine, the building without enough food is destroyed! Building some particular buildings permit to commerce with the other cities during the game. The king building all the compulsory buildings, like royal palace or ziqqurat and some other optional buildings, wins the game.

Four maps, 2 pages rules, 110 small tokens are ready to print and play!


Il gioco è dedicato agli alunni della scuola elementare che stanno studiano la civiltà dei Sumeri.

Coltiva i tuoi campi, raccogli i frutti del tuo lavoro, ingrandisci la tua città!

Intende simulare i rapporti tra le città della Mezzaluna Fertile e la necessità di sviluppare l\'agricoltura per la sopravvivenza.

Ogni giocatore è il re di una delle città sumere del titolo e deve ingrandire la propria città costruendo gli edifici obbligatori, come la ziqqurat e alcuni di quelli non obbligatori, facendo attenzione ad avere abbastanza cibo per tutti!

Quattro carte, un regolamento di due pagine, 110 piccole carte da ritagliare completano il gioco.
categories: Children's Game, City Building, Educational, Print & Play
mechanics: Open Drafting, Set Collection, Tile Placement

name: Starbattles Rotational Spacecraft (ROTEX)
description:
Rotational Spacecraft
1st Expansion Race Pack for Starbattles
24 New Control Sheet Diagrams
6 Page Booklet
This set introduces the 1st new race for the Starbattle game system.

This race (referred to as ROTEX)uses Rotational Type Spacecraft (Or, Flying Saucers)which bring new effects and special rules to the game.
Booklet includes all instances where the ROTEX ships differ from existing ships.

Specific new rules are the barriers created by their unique drive system and the fact that every ship has VTOL capability.

Included are construction notes and charts showing tech levels and build information for the 24 ship and craft types available to a ROTEX player so they can be integrated in one off or campaign games

Also included is an encounter chart for determining random opposing forces. This chart includes fleet types form the original game and it's supplement as well as all three expansion sets.

The Control Sheet Diagrams like previous sets are meant for photocopying and only have the shields, armor and engines established. This leaves the player to determine the internal makeup and armament of each ship allowing for a very customizable game experience.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Magna Carta
description:
Magna Carta is a casual two-player card game with a medieval theme sporting easy to learn and play rules.

The players take turns drawing cards from a common draw pile, deploying troop cards, supporters cards and resources cards from their hand to the table in front of them and then attacking the opponent cards with the cards on the table.
Each attack determines the number of cards the attacker draws from the draw pile as victory spoils.
When the draw pile is exhausted, the game ends and the player with the most victory spoils wins.

The game includes 90 cards with various units like Infantry, Cavaly e t c, support cards like Fortress, Blacksmith e t c. Resources are the same cards but played face down.
Several special units and supporters exist with special abilities which affects game play.
Each troop/supporter card has deployment requirements, meaning that you need to deploy them in the right order.
categories: Card Game, Medieval, Print & Play, Wargame

name: Asterisk
description:
Asterisk is an abstract connection game in which players aim to create several connections at once. It is a descendant of the Game of Y.

Each player has three goals: to connect the three sides of the board with pieces of his or her own color (dark or light), shape (hexagonal or circular), and marking (asterisked or empty). But none of the pieces will serve all three of a player's goals, so every piece played potentially benefits the opponent. There are a limited number of pieces of each type.

The winner is the player to make two or more of his or her connections.
mechanics: Hexagon Grid, Network and Route Building

name: Clash: Ascension of the Elements – Lightning Expansion
description:
Clash: Ascension of the Elements – Lightning Expansion adds the element of Lightning to the existing six elements.

Destructive and short lived, lightning seeks to leave its mark on the world by destroying the other elements. In its fury to destroy, Lightning sometimes creates Fire and Light in its wake.

name: Monopoly: England Football Stars Limited Edition
description: The World Cup is around the corner and stakes are high for England. Take on this limited edition and place your bids for the best players and venues from all over Britain. From our biggest stars, such as Joe Hart or Frank Lampard, to heroes from England's illustrious past, like Gary Lineker or David Beckham.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Kronstadt 1921
description:
This wargame tells a valorous page of the Russian Revolution: the revolt of the sailors and workers of the fleet base of Kronstadt against the rude attitude and program of the Bolshevik Soviet. Even if the rebellion was put by an end by violence, Lenin adapted some of the requests with the NEP at the X Congress.

ATTENTION: it is a diceless game!
categories: Print & Play, Wargame, World War I

name: QuestionTime!
description:
QuestionTime! is a game about Australian politics and political history. It involves strategy, knowledge, luck, intuition and rat cunning.

QuestionTime! has been designed to give everyone a chance to win. There are strategy cards to undermine other players and opportunities to form coalitions to assist with difficult questions.

Pick up a card showing Professor Richard Clever and he will provide the answer to any question — and many other tactics players can adopt to enhance their own chances or impede the progress of others.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move, Storytelling, Trading

name: Domatics
description:
The object of Domatics is to teach kids the principle of addition, subtraction, multiplication and division in a fun game environment. It is designed to help children learn basic arithmetic calculations, while encouraging them to learn how to gradually speed up their mathematical calculations. The game is designed to enable players to use strategy to play efficiently. Players will need to know when to play a high tile or when to play a low tile, when to take risks and when not to. This will help to give players that preparation to analyze and make informed decisions based on their evaluations. Most importantly the game is designed to include the whole family.


Promotes family bonding & team-building
Teaches sportsmanship
Promotes socialization & Improves self-esteem
Teaches interpersonal & communication skills
Teaches arithmetic and analytical skills
Develops thinking skills and enhances decision-making
Develops cognitive and spatial abilities.


The game plays a lot like Dominioes except instead of number tiles there are addition, subtraction, multiplication and division tiles. Tiles are added to the end of other tiles just like in Dominoes except that points are gained based on the tile played. Players will then call out the correct answer to the math equation that they made and gain points if they're correct or possibly lose points if they're wrong. Special lock tiles will make it where other players can't play on that end unless they have a special unlock tile. The player whose points are closest to the target number that is rolled at the beginning of the game wins.

name: Men of Honor
description:
Men of Honor is a new generation skirmish wargame, a new 28mm miniatures game for 2 or more players controlling 2 factions that fight for the control of the city.

The modular game board allows to quickly set up the playing field in an exact and proportionate scale.
Measuring 90 x 90 cm (36 x 36”), it reproduces a part of a hypothetic north american city, with stores, shops, buildings, banks and much more.
In the box you will find 8 wonderful metal miniatures, so you can start immediately to play your first games in the fascinating Gangsters’ world!
mechanics: Action Queue, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Player Elimination, Simulation

name: Hammered: The Card-Based Fantasy Pub-Crawl Drinking Game!
description:
When playing Hammered you take on the role of a group of fun-loving dwarves. You are all out on a pub-crawl and will be visiting a number of taverns during the night. However these are strange and often dangerous lands so it is best that you stay on your guard during your night out! There are Orcs and thieves and wizards about causing all manner of mischief and mayhem!

You start out with 15 gold coins and you must spend these when you first visit a tavern. There are 5 taverns in a game but each one has its own price and exit condition. This means that you could have a cheap night or an expensive one! There are challenge cards and chance cards, some that give you gold and others that take it away!

(1) In a turn you enter a tavern > pay for a drink > take an event card and follow its instruction > end your turn.
(2) On your following turns in a tavern you roll the die > if it matches the number on the tavern you exit and repeat (1)
(3) On your following turns in a tavern you roll the die > if you fail to match the number on the tavern you stay in the current tavern > take an event card and follow its instructions > end your turn.

If you run out of gold and you can't afford to pay at a tavern then you must steal gold until you have enough to continue, but don't get caught or you'll be kicked out and must go back to the previous tavern!

The aim of the game is to buy a drink in all of the taverns on the street and be the first player to leave the final tavern. However be warned that your fellow players can buy you a round if they can afford it and keep you in the final tavern a little longer!

name: Genpei Kassen
description:
Genpei Kassen (源平合戦) is part of the 'historical' division of Bandai's 'if' series of games. It is translated as 'Genpei War'. The 'Gen' is the Chinese pronunciation of the character for Minamoto, one of the two main combatants. 'Pei' (or 'Hei) similarly refers to the Taira, so it's the 'Minamoto-Taira War'. A strategic simulation of the 1180-1185 conflict in Japan involving the Minamoto and Taira warrior houses, it reflects the fact that fighting was not done strictly along 'clan' lines by including as other factions the Kiso (a branch of the Minamoto), the Fujiwara, and the Imperial Family. The war is still a popular subject in Japan today, being immortalized by period literature such as the Heike Monogatari ('Tale of the Heike') and live performances by blind biwa (lute) players.

The game is designed for 2-4 players taking the part of one of the four main combatants-the Taira (SW Japan), Kiso (a Minamoto branch, central Japan), Minamoto (SE Japan), and Fujiwara (N Japan). There are rules for a 5th player to operate abstractly as the Insei (retired Emperor) Go-Shirakawa, meddling with the plans of the four warrior houses. There are several different scenarios involving different numbers of players and levels of conquest. Gameplay features area movement of generic land and naval forces. Armies are generic and all have the same value, and are boosted by the values of leaders accompanying them. None of the leaders are named but each has a different skill level (if you're familiar with the history, it's easy to figure out the names that go with each leader counter). Naval warfare and sea movement of troops is somewhat abstract and confined to the southern areas of the map. Cardplay has a big effect on gameplay as cards can lead to possession of the Emperor, abundant crops, famine (denying victory points), access to independent naval forces, and other events. Victory is determined by both provinces held each turn (each province is worth a varying number of points) and enemy units destroyed.

Starting positions for the game are somewhat historically inaccurate; this was done for play balance as the Kiso are facing a two front war with the other combatants initially only having one. Factions are differentiated by their leader and naval pools. The Fujiwara have no navy, three overpoweringly wealthy provinces, and have the strongest leader in the game (and an extremely strong sub-leader). The Kiso have a middling leader, no navy, 23 relatively poor provinces, and a small pool of back up leaders. The Minamoto have a solid and large leadership pool but no navy and start with 14 provinces worth a moderate amount. The Taira have the misfortune of having an excellent leader being a subordinate of the worst leader in the game, but start off with naval forces and 20 moderately valuable provinces. There are also 3 neutral provinces that can be invaded during the game. Overall, the game has a good feel for the war it seeks to recreate and the difficulties faced by each faction.

name: Hammered: The Shady Rogue Expansion
description:
This is an expansion for the game Hammered where you play as a group of dwarves on a pub-crawl. This expansion adds a shady underground style theme to the game with a new character, a new tavern and a number of event cards that give the core game a sense that there is a seedy underbelly to these quaint taverns!

The game-play is the same however the expansion adds some additional rules by giving the new character a perk, the new tavern a house rule and a couple of cards that allow other players to acquire the new perk as well. This particular perk allows players to get gold even when they lose wagers and to pay less for drinks in the new tavern, everyone else has to pay extortionate prices!
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Mature / Adult, Medieval, Party Game

name: Hammered: The Alchemist's Mark Expansion
description:
This is an expansion for the game 'Hammered' where you play as a group of dwarves on a pub-crawl. This expansion adds a magical theme to the core game with a new character, new tavern and wizard themed event cards.

The game plays the same however the addition of this expansion throws in some new rules. The new character has a perk, the new tavern has a house rule and there are a couple of cards that allow other players to acquire the perk as well. The tavern's house rule makes gold lost or spent inside the tavern turn into other commodities and the perk allows players to spend gold in order to make other players forfeit! There is also an additional rule that only comes into play if the card is drawn which makes the winner of the game perform a challenge before they can be crowned victorious!
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Mature / Adult, Medieval, Party Game

name: Level 7 [Omega Protocol]: Passage Promo
description:
The "Passage" promo card has the following text:

Room
Passage:
Place an enemy passage tile on the edge of any tile in this room. When building room stacks during setup, replace any card that spawns enemies in a room stack with this card. Set the replaced card aside.
Priority 2
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Horror, Miniatures, Science Fiction
mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Variable Player Powers

name: Level 7 [Omega Protocol]: Supply Cache Promo
description:
A promo Investigate card for Level 7 [Omega Protocol]

Supply Cache:
Draw four more Investigate Cards.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Horror, Miniatures, Science Fiction
mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: Level 7 [Omega Protocol]: SF13 Pistol Promo
description:
A Promo Kit card for Level 7 [Omega Protocol]

SF13 Pistol:
Stats: 3 Black dice Range:6

Attacks with this weapon cost one adrenaline. If this attack is against a target adjacent to you, roll three red dice instead of 3 black dice.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Horror, Miniatures, Science Fiction
mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: WOMBAT! The game of Word Combat!
description:
WOMBAT! is the one-upping, buzzer-beating, shoutout showdown countdown smackdown game of Word Combat!

A card is revealed showing a letter or combination of letters. Now, the players start shouting out words that contain that letter.

After a while, new cards are added. Players now have to shout words that contain all the letters.

The player that shouts the last word before the timer runs out, wins the round and scores the points ("donuts") printed on the letter cards.

12 minutes to play
2 to 20 players, age 7+
Everyone plays at once
New folks can jump in at any time
Easy enough for kids
Rich enough for serious word gamers
categories: Card Game, Party Game, Real-time, Word Game

name: Galactic Overlords: A Space Empire Strategy Game
description:
In Galactic Overlords, the players are challenged to guide their race from a small beginning on a rich home world and grow it into a powerful space empire. This is a full-fledged space empire game featuring exploration, expansion, exploitation of galactic resources AND space combat. However, it eschews the extermination or elimination of weaker players by allowing the stronger ones to become their overlords, thus extending to them a measure of protection.

The order of game play is on a round system where players do their empire production simultaneously in a production phase. Then the players do two actions each, in turn order, in the action phase. In their actions, players may engage their opponents by diplomacy, trade, and espionage as well as military ventures. Or they may go off on their own to explore for rewarding encounters.

The building of economic engines will not be enough to win. There is a shifting economy and there are changes to game conditions with the passing of ages. Players must be willing to abandon hard-won colonies in order to adapt to the changes. The game can be customized in many ways, one being the duration of the game can be set to any number of rounds the players want. Players can set limits on the aggression level of the game if they desire a more peaceful experience. There is a four player introductory game designed to introduce players to the basics of the game. In this "intro" game, the special alien abilities and technologies are not used, thus placing players on an equal footing.

A variety of mechanisms are employed which are designed to quash the common complaints that tend to occur in multiplayer conflict games.

There are several possible ways the game can end in addition to timing out on the last round. Players are rewarded on a point system for their accomplishments such their as economy, technology, exploration, military, cultural and diplomatic achievements. The highest score gains the win.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Variable Player Powers

name: Flip Florey's Flying Flea-rina
description:
"Step right up ladies and gents and witness the eighth wonder of the world! Flip Florey's Flying Flea-rina! These special Argentinian fleas have been trained in the arts of martial combat and acrobatics for your entertainment and edification! Watch them perform amazing acts of aerialist acumen. See them fight and spar as the ancient gladiators of lore. Experience a singular event of epic and microscopic proportions. Flip Florey's Flying Flea-rina will amaze and astound you!"

In Flea-rina, the players compete with their fleas to perform amazing stunts while making glorious attacks against each other. Each turn, the players select a stunt with a movement path. They then roll dice trying to match the icons on the stunt. Completing the stunt reaps victory points by entertaining the crowd. If they fail to complete the stunt they may still move along the path up to the icons rolled and may collect resources off the board and/or attack the other fleas. Fighting fleas also entertain the the crowd, gaining victory points with gladiatorial skill.

When the players have depleted all the resources on the board or when one flea has been defeated, the game is over and the player who has entertained the crowd the most wins.
mechanics: Action Queue, Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck

name: Rats in Top Hats
description:
The grand feast for the nest is tonight! A group of fancy rats are sent out into town to scavenge for the ingredients that are needed to make the feast a success. However, a cat and a ratcatcher are looking to catch the rats. Each rat has a special ability that can help ensure victory. With a little luck and some skill, the rats will find what they need in town, all the while wearing dapper hats, of course!

Players, as rats, collect Food cards to place in their buffets to complete Entrees given to them at the start of the game. To collect Food cards, players roll a die and move into different locations, such as a bakery or a butcher shop. There are five different types of food: Bread, Fruit, Meat, Vegetable, and Cheese.
