The different locations offer these types of Food. For example, when a rat enters the Cheese Shop, he or she draws a card from the Cheese deck. Or, when a rat enters the Pastry Shop, he or she draws a card from either the Bread deck OR the Fruit deck.

Then, the rats add cards to their buffets from their hands, but only one at a time. After that, the player switches into the role of the cat and/or ratcatcher. He or she rolls the Enemy die and moves the cat and/or ratcatcher accordingly. When the cat enters the same tile as a rat, he or she must discard a card in hand. When the ratcatcher enters the same tile as a rat, he or she must lose a card from his or her buffet. So, players can use the cat and ratcatcher to keep other rats in check if a player is getting too far ahead.

The game moves to a final turn when a player has ten Food cards in his or her buffet OR when any Food deck runs out of cards. Then, the player with the most points, when adding up all of his or her Entrees and Food cards, wins the game.
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Modular Board, Set Collection, Variable Player Powers

name: Konog
description:
An elegant game based off the traditional gambling game of the fierce and reclusive konog species, a secretive and xenophobic race from a remote corner of the galaxy. This game, enjoyed for years by the expeditionaries and pioneers in the Industrial Sectors, has only recently been introduced to the Core Systems.

The goal of the game is to make a number of "Konogs"; which is either three cards of the same number of any suit, or a run (1, 2, 3) of three cards of the same suit. After playing a Konog, the fourth card left in your hand is placed in front of you, this is the value of that Konog. At the end of the game (after one player has performed a sixth Konog and all other players have taken one last turn) these values are added together (plus any triumvirates) to find the player's total ending score. The player with the highest score is the winner.

Note: you will need a large plate (or a rotating tray, like a Lazy Susan) to play Konog. As a player discards, many cards will make the discard piles (one for each player) rotate in different directions. Also included in the game are wooden "sentries", you can place these on a discard pile to protect a card from being taken or covered up by another player.

Konog has many features that set it apart from other games. Inside each game box you can expect to find: simple, yet elegant artwork featured on circular cards, a completely alien numerical system based on three (don't worry, standard numbers are featured at the bottom of each card for those that are unfamiliar with the Konog numeral system), colorful wooden pieces (a sentry and matching post for each player), and a drawstring bag to hold everything.

name: Time Fight
description:
Time Fight is a gladiatorial combat game where your fighters can travel through time, revive dead fighters and change the game's history.

In Time Fight, each player controls a squad of 3 Fighters. Players then move their Fighters across space-time, leaving behind a trails of their past selves. These past selves can be intersected, fought and killed, altering the history of the game so far.

For instance, if a Fighter is killed, another Fighter in their squad can go back in time and kill their killer before they were killed, reviving them.

Play Summary

Each Player starts with 3 Fighters on a 2-dimensional board (one dimension is space, one is time). Each turn, players activate a square with one of their Fighters, which either activates combat (if enemies are in the square), or allows that Fighter to move. Combat is decided via secretly selected cards for each Fighter. Some moves allow the Fighters to travel in time, but will, over time, lock off the board to Time Travel, preventing others from doing the same.

Fighters can also grab items in the square they're in, which will give them extra abilities in their future.

Players get Victory Points for:

having living Fighters,
killing other Fighters,
having Fighters with long timelines,
travelling backwards in time; and
grabbing VP items on the board


The Fight ends when an entire squad is dead, most of the board is locked, or a player reaches 8 Victory Points.

name: Escape From Planet Pook
description:
Can the robots collect enough crystals to escape planet Pook?
The robot's ship has run out of fuel and crash landed on the mysterious planet of Pook. They need to collect enough crystals so they can leave. The only problem is the aliens that live there want the crystals for themselves and don't feel like sharing.

Escape From Planet Pook has 4 game modes for up to 16 players!

Play as the robots (1-8 players), get enough crystals to escape the planet!
Play as the aliens (1-8 players), stop the robots from stealing all your crystals!
Play as aliens vs. robots (2-16 players), robots try to take crystals to their ship and the aliens try to take the crystals to their cave (they use them as night lights).
Play Crystalball! (2-16 players), a super cool sport played by the aliens and robots, just for fun!


Escape From Planet Pook features modular game tiles, awesome artwork, an easy to remember alien/robot A.I. (in the Aliens or Robots modes all the players play against the game and the A.I. controls the opposing models for you!). Each alien and robot has their own unique power as well! Escape From Planet Pook also features a bonus micro card deck as well, so you can play your favorite card games on the go!

The game also has many features and suggestions for scalable difficulty. Don't let the cute artwork fool you, this is a complete game (or complete set of 5+ games!). You can make this game easy enough for any kid to beat it or impossibly hard for an adult. Are you ready to explore the planet of Pook?
categories: Children's Game, Humor, Science Fiction, Sports
mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Modular Board, Pick-up and Deliver, Variable Player Powers

name: ShadowSea: Campaign Chronicles
description:
From the Publisher:

The column of energy began twisting uncontrollably, taking on a much darker hue of green and orange, shooting bolts of lightning in all directions. It was then that the tonic must have affected my vision for I could see a tranformation of the fire column. It must have been the tonic, I keep telling myself now, but there was something erupting from the column, snaking around men and pulling them, screaming, into the flames. The thousands of mouths filled with teeth, surrounded by flailing tentacles. . . clouds of foul smoke in the air, choking and vile. . . no, it must have been a vision. . .

A skirmish campaign for the ShadowSea miniatures game.
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Variable Phase Order

name: Blades of Honor: An Epic Game of Samurai Adventure in Medieval Japan.
description:
BACKGROUND: Blades of Honor is an adventure game for 1-4 Players, where the players assume the roles of young Samurai in Late Medieval Japan (1450-1600). Each Player creates a Samurai Character in the service of a minor Lord called a Hatamoto. As a loyal retainer, the Player-Samurai must complete various assignments for his Hatamoto such as escorting envoys, participating in Battles, dueling rival Samurai, framing rival Hatamoto, and assassinations. As your Samurai gains experience and renown they can improve their attributes and eventually prove their worth in order to one day, become a Hatamoto himself and possibly the Provincial Lord or Daimyo!

GAME OBJECTIVE: The Objective of each Player-Samurai is to become the Daimyo of his Province. In order to become a Daimyo, the Player-Samurai must accomplish the following:
1. Samurai must complete Assignments to earn enough Renown Points to be selected as Hatamoto during the Dynasty Phase of the Player Turn.
2. Once he is a Hatamoto, the Player Samurai must earn enough Renown Points to be selected as Daimyo during the Dynasty Phase or after all Rival Hatamoto have been conquered or eliminated.

GAME FEATURES: Blades of Honor features a flavorful Large-Hex Map with Villages, Castles, Mountains, Paddies, Forests and Rivers. Also, there are many, many colorful counters of Samurai, Ronin, Bandits, Bushi Warriors, Monks, and various mythologcal creatures and monsters!

This is basically a Role-Playing Boardgame of Epic Adventure. If you are a fan of Samurai movies and legends, then this is the game for you.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Role Playing

name: Space & Sea Battle
description:
An electronic version of the classic Battleship game.
The main difference between this game and regular Electronic Battleship / Electronic Sea Battle, is the inclusion of space crafts alongside the regular navel vessels. These space crafts have a very different shape when compared to the naval vessels and thus have their own unique limitations of placement on the board.

Other features:

electronic setup and targeting
player-versus-CPU mode
Salvo fire mode (fire 5 shots at once)
Live-action mode (be the first to respond to a signal to earn the right to fire a shot)

name: UNITY 6×6×6 Expansion Set
description: This Expansion Set for UNITY allows 2–3 players to play on a 6×6×6 hex-hex grid, a 49% bigger playfield than in the base game.

name: Hexagonal Wars
description: Hexagonal Wars is a flexible strategy game for 2 to 4 players. Despite being easy to learn, it is a complex game. You have to think over each of your moves carefully. Each player has to plan and conform to every situation and control a team that they assembled, while their goal is to kill the enemy forces. One big advantage of the game is that every match is different, because the war maps, units, and cards all guarantee a variety of gameplay for unlimited replayability!
mechanics: Action Queue, Area Majority / Influence, Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Grid Movement

name: The Penguin Book of Patience
description:
From the dust jacket:

David Parlett has produced the most original and complete collection of patience games for one player (and in some cases two) for nearly a century. In it he sets out to dispel the notion that patience is a therapeutic pastime for the simple-minded and the idle rich. Whereas previous compilations have tended to copy one another in jumbling good, bad, and indifferent games with no sense of order, the author has here adopted a systematic approach enabling the browser to pick out the type of game most appealing to his or her own taste and mood of the moment. Three major groups are distinguished. First come the attractive and simple games requiring care and patience to bring them out, then games requiring a balance of judgement and card sense and finally those which call for the type of positional analysis more usually associated with chess problems than card games. Each group is further subdivided in a way which generally proceeds from the small and simple to the large and complex.

name: Friendly Fire Pack 9
description:
Friendly Fire Pack 9 contains eight scenarios featured in the Friendly Fire 2014 Advanced Squad Leader tournament. The scenarios are:

FrF69 To Ashes by Matthias Ronnblom
France 1940 British vs. Germans, 6 turns, 3 maps
A German force mostly composed of infantry and towed Guns had to push across open fields to rescue a small German force about to face 12 light British AFV.

FrF70 An Estonian interlude by Erik Leander
USSR 1941 Soviets vs. Estonians, 7 turns, 1 map
Small scenario in which both sides have to rush to a building, possibly taking parallel paths along the board 23 canal.

FrF71 Pulling out by Matthias Ronnblom
USSR 1942 Germans vs. Soviets, 7 turns, 2 maps including the excellemt FrFA map
To simulate confusion, two Soviet AFVs will randomly turn abandoned at the consternation of the Soviet side.

FrF72 The Mubo Decision by Andrew Rogers
New Guinea 1943 Australian vs. Japanese, 5 turns, 2 half-maps
An attack - counterattack bloodbath.

FrF73 Sledgehammers by Peter Struijf and Chris Mazzei
France 1944 Germans vs. British, 6 turns, 2 maps
Low quality infantry supported by 150mm SPAs attacking HIP British commandos.

FrF74 Out of their Element by Matthias Ronnblom
Poland 1944 Germans vs. Soviets, 6.5 turns, 2 half-maps

FrF75 Goodbye Brother by Matthias Ronnblom
Finland 1944 Finns vs. Germans , 6 turns, 2 half-maps
Includes as optional German seaborne assault against the Finns.

FrF76 Pain in the Neck by Michael Koch
Germany 1945 Soviets vs. Germans =, 6.5 turns, 2 half-maps
Retreating SS troops with two captured Shermans run into a small Soviet detachment.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: CardBots: Build & Destroy
description:
CardBots: Build & Destroy is a customizable mech battle card game.

Use resources granted by tech cards to fill slots and build out a 2D mech, directly on your tabletop. Then utilize game altering special abilities and powerful weapons to destroy your opponents!

Game rules, card gallery, and a free full version of the game can be downloaded as a print & play pack at http://www.cardbotsccg.com

EDIT: Link not working anymore, you can find the game on http://www.geremygeorge.com/cardbots
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Player Elimination

name: Malifaux: Arsenal Box – Arcanists (Wave 2)
description: The fate of Malifaux is approaching a crossroads. Forces continue to vie for power, as new allies join the struggle. Contained in this Arsenal Deck you will find all the stat and upgrade cards needed to play the Guild characters and crews found in the Malifaux 2E: Crossroads book.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Horror, Miniatures

name: The Northern Theatre of Operations 1939-40
description:
The Northern Theatre of Operations 1939-40 is an effort to expand the existing EUROPA games both in scale and scope; in scale by making game components and time frames EUROPA standard, in scope by adding an extensive naval module to the rules set, by starting the game at an earlier date, and by expanding the theatre of operations to the entire Scandinavian peninsula.[...]
The campaign begins with the Axis player turn of Dec I 1939.

(from the introduction)



Contents:

Rules (39 pages)
Naval Tables (2 pages)
National Data Sheets (Sweden, Finland, Norway, Denmark, Germany, Soviet Union, France, Britain)
Order of battle notes (7 pages)
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: Children's Business
description: In the game Children’s business, the players take turns in trying to explain how different intricate situation at various example situations from the business world affect children. The game is meant to be an ice-breaker, thought provoker and basis of discussion in internal work groups at companies where projects concerning Unicefs The Childrens Rights and Busines Principles are initiated and developed.

name: Combat Leader: Volkssturm '45 Expansion Module
description:
From the publisher's web site:

This is the second expansion module for the Combat Leader game system. It introduces the German Volkssturm forces available near the end of the war. You must own Combat Leader: East Front '41 to use this expansion.

It includes a counter sheet (Set D) with 27 Volkssturm men, and a new 12-man Russian first line squad, as well as Map 5 (8.5"x11"), additional Reference Card, and instruction folder. New rules cover the use of Volkssturm in scenarios, and special rules governing their use. Also instructions governing the use of improvised weapons (such as antique rifles, shotguns, the MP 3008, and panzerfausts) are provided. Finally, Scenario VKS-1 (Outskirts of Berlin) lets you use the new components in a situation set in Greater Berlin, May 1945.

Like the previous expansion, this one builds on the foundation provided in the core rules, and is compatible with any Combat Leader game.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: Eat the Villagers
description:
Eat the Villagers was invented to get friends off their cell phones and laughing together. It's portable and meant to be taken to dinner with you, played between the time you order and when your food arrives.

This is a family-friendly dice game that takes 5 minutes to learn and 15-20 minutes to play. It is suitable for 2-10 players and can be learned by children as young as 5 years old. It fits in your pocket and travels well, so it makes a great game to leave in the car, take to the laundromat, take to dinner with you, or pack in your carry-on luggage.

Rules
Each player rolls 5 randomly selected dice, separating the Knights, Villagers, and Barricades, as well as any special dice. Barricades get rerolled, drawing up to 5 more dice to roll each turn.

You may stop any time and return to your lair, eating the number of Villagers on the board. That number is added to your next turns, until you have 15 or more, and are full, winning the game.

5 Knights vanquishes the dragon, ending your turn with 0 points.

If you roll a Wizard (one of the specialty dice), he casts his Magic if and only if 2 Knights are on the board to protect him. Wizard's Magic vanquishes the dragon, ending your turn with 0 points. Without 2 Knights, he counts as a Villager.

If you roll a Dragon (the other specialty dice), you cast your Fire Breath attack. This burns all Barricades, revealing the delicious Villager goodness inside. It also melts the armor of 1 Knight, taking that die out of play. Then the Dragon also goes out of play. Count the Villagers and return to your lair or continue your turn, at your choice.

Play continues until some dragon/player has eaten 15 or more Villagers and is satiated. Everyone left in that round of play still gets a turn to try and beat the high score.
categories: Dice, Fantasy, Humor, Medieval, Party Game

name: Crossy Magnetic
description: Crossy magnetic is a word game in which two to four players score points by placing tiles, each bearing a single letter, onto a gameboard. The tiles must form words which, in crossword fashion, flow left to right in rows or downwards in columns. The words must be defined in a standard dictionary.

name: Automobile: Chicken – 2 Player Variant
description:
2 Player Variant for Martin Wallace's Automobile. Includes 6 tiles and a rule sheet. Released with Mayfair Games' Limited Edition Promo Expansion Set #6

Starting The Game


Each player receives 6 RD cubes.
Place character tiles into an opaque bag or container and mix them. *Draw 2 character tiles and place these tiles on their character tiles in the character boxes. These characters are out of play for the first round.
Next, draw 2 more character tiles, placing them on the empty space in the turn track box. These characters will be out of play the following round.
Set aside the salesman pieces of 1 color; these will be neutral.
Place 1 advertisement marker (white) on each of the first 2 spaces.
Place 2 discount markers (gray) on the first gray space and 1 on the second space.
The third spaces will not be used in this variant (you can cover these with a factory from an unused color.)
Remove 2 “5” value and 1 “4” value demand tiles from the game.


P2: Select Characters


You may not select characters that have a character tile currently on them.


P3: Player Actions

II: Place Salesman


When you place your salesman you must place 1 neutral salesman, in addition to your allowed pieces, in 1 of the same showrooms that you occupied with this action.


P5: Sell Cars Via Salesman


When it comes to your turn and you have decided to sell a car or pass, you must move one of the neutral pieces to 1 of the sales tracks to the left. Before being moved to the sales track a neutral salesman can be moved up or down a maximum of 1 segment.


P9: End of Turn


Remove the character tiles from the character boxes and return them into the opaque bag or container. Move the 2 character tiles in the turn track box onto the appropriate character boxes; these characters are now out of play for this round. Draw 2 new character tiles, and place these on the empty space in the turn track box.
Each player places 1 closed factory marker onto the first open space beyond their farthest factory built.

name: To Reign Supreme
description:
To Reign Supreme is a 2 player area control war game that uses 18 cards. Each player battles to conquer 6 contested Territories, using the abilities of the territories to build their military and increase their wealth. Battles are conducted via a card based mechanic that limits chance and increases decision based strategy.

Each player has 5 Military Strategy cards and can choose 3 to use throughout the game. Each player starts with the same 5 Military Strategy cards, differing only in card color, and must choose the three that best match their intended strategy. The other two cards and the 2 Rules cards are used to track Wealth, Military, and Battle specific stats for their country.
categories: Card Game, Fantasy, Medieval, Print & Play
mechanics: Action Points, Area Majority / Influence, Campaign / Battle Card Driven

name: My Big Break
description:
My Big Break is a board game about auditioning in musical theatre. Components of the game are pawns, dice, money, credits, bitter cards, closing cards, and the board pieces. The general idea is that players go on gigs and accumulate a resume in the form of credits so that they eventually are qualified and ready to audition for their 'Big Break'. Booking this gig wins the game.
Player take turns. Each turn has four phases. The first is an income phase, where players earn credits and/or money (except when in NYC, where they have to pay to live there). The second phase is an audition phase where they roll dice to see if they are cast in a gig. The third phase is a movement phase. The last phase the players either can play a 'bitter card' or they 'take class'. Playing a bitter card generally has a detrimental effect on another player. Taking class involves exchanging money and other resources to gain special advanced credits.

Bitter cards are generally earned by failing to book auditions. Closing cards are earned by completing professional gigs. Specialty Credits are required to audition for more advanced gigs, such as Cruise Line and Bus 'N Truck. A player must possess all three specialty credits (acting, vocal, and dance) and must have 15 total credits or more to audition for their 'Big Break'. If a player fails this audition, he/she loses an advanced credit, a generic credit, and gains two bitter cards. Play continues until somebody books their 'Big Break'.

A future expansion of My Big Break is planned which will contain the option to work for a Theme Park and a Dinner Theatre. Players will also be able to wait tables in NYC and take an agent there.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Take That

name: Duckies in Lofoten
description:
A merchant ship carrying thousands of small plastic duckies has shipwreck in the middle of the ocean. Duckies have fallen into the water and have swept away by the current to Lofoten islands (Norway). Duckies are cute and funny, but they endanger the ecosystem of the islands.

Fishermen, seeing them go to sea to fish with their nets. But it will not be easy at all: a strong storm, heavy seas, ice sheets, and several orcas will complicate the task.

Game inspired by a true story that occurred in 1992. A merchant ship lost in the middle of the ocean 29,000 plastic duckies. The little duckies are still adrift on the seas of the world. The oceanographer Curtis Ebbesmeyer follows their trail since. Thanks to him, nowadays we know more about ocean currents.

OBJECTIVE
in Duckies in Lofoten players are sailors and have to cooperate tile by tile, chosing the correct action dices, in order to build the best strategy. They are not alone, an Icebreaker will help them to fish all the duckies before to be catched by ice.
categories: Children's Game, Collectible Components, Educational, Environmental, Nautical
mechanics: Area Movement, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Tile Placement

name: Gargoyles Gigantik Game
description:
Spin the spinner and move your playing piece clockwise around the board. Object of the game is to collect he most Gargoyle character playing cards as possible and to get rid of as many Xanatos and/or Demona cards collected during the game as you can before the game ends.

After all 32 cards in the deck have been played, players may disregard all spaces landed on except the Elisa Maza space. As soon as a player lands on any Castle Space the game ends. The winner is the player with the most points at the end of the game. Points are scored by number of Gargoyle character cards you have. Each card is worth one point. If any players have Xanatos and/or Demona cards, subtract one point each from your score.
categories: Children's Game, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Tower Seven
description:
Tower Seven puts you in the shoes of a 1980s action hero. During a public unveiling of Tower Corporation's new product, terrorists have taken over the main facility and are searching for a dangerous technology prototype. Trapped in the building, it's up to you to find what they are after, thwart their escape, and save the hostages.

Tower Seven is a cooperative strategy card game set in a 1980s office tower that has been taken over by terrorists. Via exploration, card play and die rolls, you will battle villains to find items and clues of their ultimate plan.

To win, you must find all the clues, recover the item card the clues pointed you towards, stop the escape plan, and ultimately defeat the final boss. The game includes a Threat Level mechanic that rises when certain events occur in-game. If the Threat Level reaches too high, hostages may be executed and you may lose the game.

Upon winning, a scoring system helps you determine how well you did versus the game. Multiple variants and difficulty levels are available to aid replayability.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Hand Management

name: ACHTUNG!
description:
When your two choices are make laws, or go to prison, you’ll scrape the bottom of the barrel to stay free.

ACHTUNG! is an abstract strategy game about creating a multitude of pointless laws and annoying rules for everyone in the game to follow.

As players draw and play cards, the number of laws continues to build until it becomes impossible for the average player to follow them all. When a player breaks a law, and someone else notices, they get called out by having ACHTUNG! shouted at them, and they must discard from their hand of cards. Once a player loses all of their cards, they’re put in the gulag and must catch someone else breaking a law to re-enter the game. The game is over when a lone lawmaker remains.

The gameplay is separated into 5 distinct card types: Global Laws that everyone at the table must follow, Directed Laws that only effect a single player, Amendments that modify the text of cards already on the table, Filibusters that interrupt the main-game for a chance to win valuable cards, and Abolish cards that remove other cards from play.

ACHTUNG! is currently in its second edition. The second edition contains updates to the first edition rules and cards, such as allowing players to place markers on law cards to point out individual laws to play. Adjustments have also made to the Filibuster cards in the second edition to speed up gameplay.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Action / Dexterity, Card Game, Humor, Memory, Party Game
mechanics: Acting, Memory, Player Elimination, Variable Player Powers

name: Synergo
description:
Synergo is a tile-laying abstract strategy game. Each hex tile has 1-3 colors on it, and to play it onto the board it must simply agree in color on each edge with every other tile it touches.

Players get points for playing tiles. Although three different "Game Types" are outlined in the rules, the basic concept is that the more tiles you are connected to by color, the more points you score for that play.

In all game types, the winner is the player with the most points after the last tile has been played.

name: AudioMemory Game
description:
Game for children aged 3-8 years, learning foreign language (English, German or Spanish).

The educational aim of the game is to develop the sense of hearing (less used at school than the sense of sight) and to memorise the correct pronunciation of the foreign vocabulary.
Square cards have got pictures on one side and QR codes at the back. You set up them like in classic memory, hiding pictures. Using a special application for mobile devices (Android or iOS), produced by publisher, you scan QR codes of two cards of your choice. You will hear two recordings. If they are the same, you’ve just found the pair. Take these cards and look at the pictures to check if you understand the meaning of the foreign words. If recordings are different, it’s not a pair so it’s a next player turn.

The game is now available only in the print-and-play version (in the teacher’s pack "Memo The Dragon", www.memothedragon.pl). Mobile apps are available for free.

name: Tyrannosaurus
description:
This is a game for five players, but there are six figurines. Each player controls one figurine which represents one herbivore dinosaur. They move over one great valley in search for food and water. Winner is the player whose dinosaur eats most of the food (collects most counters). But, not everything is simple as it might seems so. More important thing of number of collected counters is their diversity!
The sixth figurine is tyrannosaurus. That figurine is moved by player when he/she finish move with his/her figurine. Tyrannosaurus is carnivore dinosaur, and if he gets him one juicy herbivore dinosaur, he eats it! (a player whose dinosaur is eaten is eliminatred)...this game is neverending race for various food and water counters, and running away from tyrannosaurus.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Collectible Components, Prehistoric

name: PaNiC STaTioNS
description:
Intended for families who enjoy strategy-based games, PaNiC STaTioNS is a card game suitable for 2 to 4 players age 8 to 80.

The cards are first set out in a square to form the playing area. Some of the cards are kept back to ensure that it is more difficult to predict what you will land on. The cards are initially face-down and Tokens are placed on the cards.

The aim of the game is to collect 10 Tokens and then be the player who turns the last card face-up.

Each player has two Pawns which are moved around the cards according to the role of two dice. During the first phase of the game Tokens are collected when a player lands on the cards. The card is then turned face-up and any instructions followed. For example it could be a "Booby-Trap" card which forces your Pawn out of play. In which case you need to roll a 6 to bring it back in to play.

During the second phase of the game most of the Cards will have been turned-face up and most of the Tokens collected. It now becomes more important to keep both Pawns in play to give you some flexibility in choosing which cards you land on. You and your rivals will be trying to force Pawns out of play, trying to steal Tokens, and generally attempting to turn the last card face-up. The cards have various effects which assist (or hinder) you in this. Many of the cards interact with each other. For example if a rival's Pawn is on the "Philanthropy" card (which obliges him to give away 2 Tokens every time somebody else's Pawn goes out of play) it could be a good move to land on "Maelstrom" which forces all Pawns out of play. Most of the cards have effects that can be used to advantage in this way.
Each turn you also have the option of rolling the "Panic Die" which gives you other alternatives. You may choose to do this, for example, if your initial dice roll was particularly disadvantageous of if another player is about to win. You do however have the chance of losing half your Tokens - but even this can be turned to your advantage if you realise how.

name: 7TV On Location
description:
On Location is a 110+ pages supplement for Crooked Dice's Spy-Fi miniature game that introduces rules for playing in 6 new environments: space, desert, underwater, artic, in the dark, airborne).

In addition to these, the supplement features new gadgets, casts, episodes, etc.
categories: Miniatures, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Spies/Secret Agents

name: Sergeants D-Day: Chapter 6 Carentan
description:
Carentan is a double Story expansion that adds urban fighting to D-Day Sergeants.

Carentan is a key objective to the allied plan - and both sides know it. Fighting house to house is the only way to take it.

Includes: 32 Story cards and Map Tiles U1 - Rue Sebline and Eglise Notre-dame

(Contains; 16 tiles and 32 cards)

name: Sergeants D-Day: Chapter 7 Brecourt Manor
description:
Brecourt Manor is first of three chapters that tell the story of Brecourt Manor and the clearing of a battery of artillery.

Brecourt manor is a provincial stone manor house that commands a good view of the countryside. Taking it will be murder.

Includes: 16 Story cards and Map Tiles L18, 161, 152, 153, 154

(Contains; 8 tiles and 16 cards)

name: Dhex
description:
Dhex (from Dual-Hex) is a Hex derivative that is played with the same components.

Players in turn place 2 adjacent discs on the board, one of each colour.

Whenever a 1-cell hole is created, the player that created it places a disc of her colour on it. Notice that several holes can be created at once, but none as a result of filling.

First to connect his sides wins.

The games are shorter than in Hex, so large boards are recommended (14x14).
mechanics: Network and Route Building, Paper-and-Pencil, Tile Placement

name: Undead States of America: The Zombie War Card Game
description:
You aren't trying to escape a neighborhood filled with walking dead - that was weeks ago. This isn't about survival any more.

This is war.

The object of Undead States of America is to gather survivors and hold off the undead masses. It is up to you to rally refugees, build safe zones and lead your rag-tag forces through a psychological nightmare. In the end, you will find your army of men, women & children surrounded. Only then will you learn if you've prepared well enough to secure a future for the human race... (from the back of the box)

Players attempt to build a cadre of fellow survivors, giving them a place to stay and supplies. There are cards for survivors, supplies, military action (even a nuke!), and even for antagonists (used to fight against you). The winner is who has scored the best after surviving 4 years.

name: Dystopian Legions: Codename Iron Scorpion
description:
Codename Iron Scorpion is designed to be a self-contained game that packs a box full of fabulous models and tons of excitement. It is a perfect spring board for players wishing to immerse themselves in the Dystopian Legions Universe.

This boxed set is crammed with all you need to get to grips with the new Dystopian Legions 2.0 rules engine.
categories: Miniatures, Post-Napoleonic, Science Fiction, Wargame, World War I
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: High Frontier Lite
description: High Frontier Lite is a streamlined version of the game High Frontier. The actions and movement in the game are simplified, but the game also uses new mechanics, simulating the planets orbits. The aim of the game is to take control of different planets in the solar system.

name: Wild West Exodus: Unfinished Business – The Watchers Faction Bundle
description:
Wild West Exodus is a table top miniatures game set in a sci-fi filled 1800's America. Technology and greed rule the old west. Wild West Exodus: Unfinished Business introduces 4 new factions to the game; The Confederate Rebellion, Dark Nation, Golden Army, and The Watchers.

About The Watchers:
As the portals once again open on earth, mankind has no idea what is coming. The destructive power of the Watchers will completely strip the land of all living things. The Watchers use their Alpha leaders to guide and advance their many species of aliens. Each and every member of the Watchers knows his role in their society and follow orders without question. As their enemies attempt to stop the Watchers, the Betas drain the life energy from their bodies and transport it to their Alpha leader. This transforms the Alpha during the course of any battle into an enemy that knows every move you will make before you even make it. With inhuman weapons and a thirst for human blood, they plan to wipe mankind off the planet once and for all.

About Wild West Exodus:
Wild West Exodus is a miniatures game played by 2 to 4 players in control of the faction of their choice. In the world of WWX, every model has the potential to be a hero or a villain. The game mechanics and rule set feature exciting game play from the first dice roll. Each player will be allowed to field a posse of 6 to 60 models or more. The WWX rules have been designed to allow for scaling of the game to high or low model counts without causing rules issues.

One of the most exciting parts of the Wild West Exodus game mechanic is the reusable influence pool. The influence pool will give players the option to gamble away a set amount of tokens in return for a reroll of the dice. Be careful what you gamble on because once the tokens are committed they are lost for that turn. The D10 system gives the game life and options that round out easily and allow for quick decision making.

The Halo that each model possesses creates an area of assault around the miniature allowing for fast and deadly close combat. This helps move the game along quickly and gives each fight a more cinematic feel.

Wild West Exodus also benefits from an alternating 1-3 model activation system. This system lets both players choose the most strategic way of advancing their characters across the battle field. This means that you never have to wait more than a minute or two before taking control of your own posse for your next activation.

Each posse consists of a structured army list. All factions will have 1 Boss model, 0 to 4 Underboss models, 0 to 8 Sidekick models, and an endless amount of Hired Hands. Heavy and Light Support vehicles also make up an army list.

This really gives the gamer the option to field a force led by one mighty general commanding a horde of troops or the complete opposite.

Some gamers may choose to load up on skilled Sidekicks and Underbosses or go heavy on Hired Hands for a true horde army.

No matter what option you take, the world of Wild West Exodus will engulf you in fun and excitement from your very first game.
categories: American West, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Wild West Exodus: Unfinished Business – Dark Nation Faction Bundle
description:
Wild West Exodus is a table top miniatures game set in a sci-fi filled 1800's America. Technology and greed rule the old west. Wild West Exodus: Unfinished Business introduces 4 new factions to the game; The Confederate Rebellion, Dark Nation, Golden Army, and The Watchers.

About The Dark Nation:
Once a proud and spiritual people, the Warrior Nation has fought long and hard to keep technology out of their lands. However, the pull on its people has consumed many of their warriors, and the Dark Council has influenced even the strongest of their leaders. With the corruption spreading like a virus, the shape shifting Warrior Nation men and women become trapped in a half animal half human form left to walk the land as deformed creatures with no home. Once these proud warriors leave the guiding light of the great spirit, they are doomed to a blood thirsty life of war. Their beast and human form aide them in their battles against anyone who would dare oppose them. With weapons and technology at their side, these beasts may never be stopped.

One of the most exciting parts of the Wild West Exodus game mechanic is the reusable influence pool. The influence pool will give players the option to gamble away a set amount of tokens in return for a reroll of the dice. Be careful what you gamble on because once the tokens are committed they are lost for that turn. The D10 system gives the game life and options that round out easily and allow for quick decision making.

The Halo that each model possesses creates an area of assault around the miniature allowing for fast and deadly close combat. This helps move the game along quickly and gives each fight a more cinematic feel.

Wild West Exodus also benefits from an alternating 1-3 model activation system. This system lets both players choose the most strategic way of advancing their characters across the battle field. This means that you never have to wait more than a minute or two before taking control of your own posse for your next activation.

Each posse consists of a structured army list. All factions will have 1 Boss model, 0 to 4 Underboss models, 0 to 8 Sidekick models, and an endless amount of Hired Hands. Heavy and Light Support vehicles also make up an army list.

This really gives the gamer the option to field a force led by one mighty general commanding a horde of troops or the complete opposite.

Some gamers may choose to load up on skilled Sidekicks and Underbosses or go heavy on Hired Hands for a true horde army.

No matter what option you take, the world of Wild West Exodus will engulf you in fun and excitement from your very first game.
categories: American West, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Malifaux: The Swamp Hag – Zoraida Box Set
description: Who do Voodoo? You do Voodoo. Puppet your models or enemy ones, stab your voodoo doll with detrimental conditions to give them to your opponent or play a trickier game and make a doll of your own models to fling long range buffs at them... Zoraida also plays the card cycling game and is a Master Controller. Zoraida is Dual Faction with the Neverborn.

name: Twenty Yard Shamble
description:
In the future, sooner than you’d bet on…

As the world progressed towards the future, the wealthy elite one-percenters found themselves losing their passions. Golf’s formerly exclusive clubs were opened to the masses, horse racing was banned as cruel, and auto racing was found to be not "carbon credit cost effective". The elite needed a new pastime.

Fortunately for them, a new class of mass-spectacle gladiators was found. Questionable lab projects involving human-cloning, attempting to solve the world’s worst diseases, created a global zombie pandemic. Luckily, the crisis was put down quickly – but the lab-created undead still existed.

Someone with a bit of redneck, and way too much time, picked up a few up zombie “assets” at a company bankruptcy liquidation. After a little tinkering, he managed to build a control collar contraption. When a zombie was outfitted with a collar, a skillful operator could, sort-of, get the zombies to walk in a straight line. Conveniently, the undead had no legal rights, which made them the perfect attraction.

A viral video and a crowd-sourced funding campaign later, these not-so-intelligent shamblers were being billed as the latest thing in racing spectacles. Wealthy backers quickly formed teams, a league and championship cup was created, and the wealthy few who could afford the labs, zombie jockeys, and all that related to it now had a new prestigious exclusive club.

As with all good clubs, betting became part of the social fun. As one could never really count on one’s zombie to come through, betting for, or even against one’s own entry into the race was not only allowed, it was encouraged!

While these new zombie drivers competed against each other for the series championship, the owners had their own prestige cup based on bets, side bets, crowd ratings and worse.

Bet on your friends zombie driver to make the podium … SURE! Bet on your zombie to place third … WHY NOT? WIN when your zombie shambles over the line backwards … CHECK!

Welcome to the wacky, zany, risky but always crazy world of high stakes championship zombie racing!

In Twenty Yard Shamble, players are owners of racing zombies. They pit their zombie against the other zombies, in a series of 3 races, out of an arena where armed Hunters and helpless Victims prowl. Zombies move in a semi-controlled fashion based on dice rolls. The arena has 6 finish lines spaced equally around the outside edge. The first zombie to cross a finish line is first, and earns points for it's owner AND anyone who bet on it. The second zombie to cross gets second, and the third zombie gets third. After the third zombie crossed a line, the crowd gets bored, and all remaining zombies are shot and killed.

During a race, players place bets on any of the racing zombies, including their own. If a players zombie is not performing well, that player can place a bet on another player's zombie who is performing better, and may be able to help that zombie finish better in the race.

At the end of 3 races, the player with the most points wins.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid

name: Strange Conversations
description:
Strange Conversations is a humorous social game for 3 to 7 players that tests players' abilities to convey hints about their secret identities to one another throughout the course of a simple role-played sit-down conversation.

In each game players find themselves in an interesting hypothetical setting and scenario having a conversation with a group of people with strange and often funny personality quirks.

At the start of each round, each player is assigned a secret JOB and a secret character QUIRK. For example, a player may be an olympic athlete (job) whose hands keep getting stuck to the table (quirk). Or, a doctor (job) who offers other players back-handed compliments (quirk). Or, a dancing instructor (job) who is hitting on other players (quirk).

With inspiration from a random scenario, players role-play a discussion and provide clues to each other about what their two qualities (job/quirk) are.

There are no "turns" in this game. Conversations are free-flowing discussions where players may ask and answer questions whenever appropriate. Players drop creative hints about their identities through the use of verbal hints, including puns and keywords related to their jobs, hints to aspects of their jobs, and cultural references. Players may also use physical gestures to help convey their identities.

Players earn the most points if they can signal what their jobs and quirks are to some -- but not all -- other players, and also earn points for guessing who other players are.

name: Arkham Nights
description:
Arkham Nights is a party game set in the world of H.P. Lovecraft. Players are assigned characters randomly and form two separate groups, the Townsfolk and the Investigator(s).

During the Day phase, each Investigator may ask one Townsfolk a question to help determine who is the hidden Cultist. The Investigator(s) may then choose to kill one Townsfolk if they wish. Some Townsfolk are Madmen who have an ability which is triggered when they are killed, others are Monsters who then challenge the Investigator who killed them.

Next is the Night phase, when the Investigator(s) leave the room to discuss what they have discovered during Day. Meanwhile, the Townsfolk determine how they can best help the Cultist succeed. Some Townsfolk are Madmen who have an ability which is triggered if they choose to permanently reveal their character. Finally, the Cultist chooses to either use a Relic, or remove a Ritual token from Cthulhu (represented by the Moderator).

If the final Ritual token is removed, the game ends with the Cultist and all the Townsfolk winning, living or dead. However, if the Investigator(s) managed to kill the Cultist during the previous Day phase, and the Cultist is still dead at the end of Night, the Investigators win and stop the ritual from completing.
mechanics: Acting, Cooperative Game, Memory, Player Elimination, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers, Voting

name: Tank Platoon: West Front – A Solitaire Game of WWII Armored Combat on the Western Front.
description:
Tank Platoon: West Front is a solitaire game of Armored Combat in Western Europe during World War II. The player assumes the role of a Tank Platoon Leader responsible for securing your Sector of Advance by successfully taking and holding key objectives with the least amount of casualties. Although there are many support units available to you, they may often times be limited to you by political, logistical or geographical obstacles.

GAME OBJECTIVE
The objective of Tank Platoon is to successfully take and secure a number of key objectives and destroy enemy forces in order to gain Victory Points (VP) for your Nation’s Forces. Once all Objectives have been secured or the Campaign Deck is exhausted, the Campaign is considered over. The Player must then total his VP and compare this with the Victory Determination Table to determine the level of success.

GAME FEATURES
Tank Platoon features many colorful counters and includes many combat units including M-24 Chaffees, M-4A1 and M4A3 Shermans, M-26 Pershings, PZ-IVf1s, PZ-IVf2s, PZ-V Panthers, PZ-VI Tigers and a variety of Infantry, ATG and support weapons. Your Tank Crews have the ability to improve their ratings and gain Tank Upgrades.

Optional Rules allow the Player to play as a British Commonwealth Tank Platoon with M5 Stuarts, Mk.VI Cromwells, Mk.VII Churchills and M4A3 Shermans.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid

name: Knowledge Battle
description: Your opponent will ask you questions about a specific issue.You have to answer correctly as many as possible to win and learn!

name: Ristorante Assassino
description:
A murder mystery dinner-style party game in which each player is assigned a role and players try to find out who the murderer is. Each player has his/her own information booklet, and five game rounds are spent discussing clues and inconsistencies until players vote on who to accuse of the murder.

The setting for this case is downtown Manhattan, 1981. The members of the Assassino clan are having a meeting at Ristorante Assassino when Vico, son and right hand of Don Assassino is found murdered at the lavatory.

name: Rogue Planet
description:
Welcome to Rogue Planet! A derelict world where you can experience true sci-fantasy gaming that allows you to fight skirmishes that focus on the cinematics and action of the genre without skimping on the tactics. It features:


ROGUE Die Mechanic
PAWN System
FX Phyisics Engine
Skill Based Combat
ENERGY Expenditure System
No labor intensive bookkeeping!
No measuring!
Custom point based force creation
Equipment and Upgrades
Sorcery and Psionics
Multiple game levels
Scenarios


-Play Aids

INNOVATIVE SYSTEMS
ROGUE DIE™ | The ROGUE DIE mechanic allows you to counteract your enemies’ actions during their turns and fuels your powered weapon, powered armor, and psionic force weapon abilities and effects. Counter-actions include things like: dodging, returning ranged fire, counter casting, and intercept maneuvers.

PAWN SYSTEM™ | The innovative PAWN system provides a unique mechanism for representing your leader’s retinue and followers and makes for dynamically changing battles as your hero loses abilities, power, and support during a game. PAWNS are also a prime feature of the campaign system and allow a leader to gain new abilities, change strategies, and evolve as a adventure progresses.

Pawns include: ammo grunts, bots, expendables, familiars, intimidators, and brutes [and many more!]. Who will follow you into battle?

FX | The FX Physics Engine™ powers the epic throws, collisions, and staggering blows on ROGUE PLANET. It also gives players the option to make the battlefield more interactive with the implementation of destructible, throwable, and treacherous terrain types. Want to throw an orc in powered armor halfway across the battlefield into a group of goblins and see what survives? FX makes it happen!

ENERGY | The ENERGY expenditure system allows you to simulate the strength of your force, powers the various armor ratings of your troops, and gives you the option to keep your units in play when you want or need to- but there’s always a cost!

STREAMLINED GAMEPLAY
GOT SKILLS? | Actions on ROGUE PLANET are a measure of skill. You’ll find no ‘buckets-of-dice’ or straight-line probabilities here. The interactive skill check system means that all players are constantly involved in the game, and you’ll need to work for the best possible tactical advantage or risk having your opponent counter you and take advantage of your failures.

NO BOOKKEEPING! | There are no hit point boxes, extensive tables, or detailed stat tracking on ROGUE PLANET™. Not only that, but there are no chits, tokens, spell, psionic, or effect markers littering the table either. The focus is always on the miniatures, terrain, and action on the table.

MEASUREMENT? | There are no measuring sticks, grids, rulers, centimeters, or inches used for the game. Measurements are based on the relative position of units, line-of-sight [LOS], terrain, and the in-game FX Physics Engine™.

CREATE WHAT YOU WANT
CUSTOM FORCE CREATION | Point based unit creation system gives you total control to bring your force to the tabletop in the way you envision it.

EQUIPMENT AND UPGRADES | There are over 30 different types of base weapons, armor ratings, and enhancements in the game that be used by themselves to equip your troops or combined with one another to create almost limitless supply of custom combi-weapons. These upgrades include: axes, blades, lances, blasters, heavy launchers, powered armor, powered fists, gravity hammers, chained blades, psionic force weapons, and grenades.

SORCERERS AND PSYCHERS | What sci-fantasy world would be complete without the inclusion of sorcerers and psychers. Heroes on ROGUE PLANET can be either [or both!] and wield powers like: psionic throw, anchor, time stop, magic missile, blink, deflection, and more. May the psionic force be with you space wizard- always.

PLAY HOW YOU WANT
GAME TYPES | There are multiple levels of play that allow players with various collection sizes and gameplay preferences to enjoy the game and have it grow with them. Patrols, Strikes, Missions, and Extended Ops ensure that there’s always a new way to experience adventures and combat on this derelict world. For example, during Extended Ops, your heroes may not only gain new followers but just might gain [or become] a nemesis.

SCENARIOS | The included scenarios range from simple battles to ambushes and there are also options for unique modes-of-play featuring ROGUE elements.

name: God Plays Dice
description:
It is a millisecond second after the Big Bang. Now is your chance to guide the creation of particles, fundamental forces, and the physical laws of the rapidly expanding universe and use them to your advantage. Through judicious planning and aggressive maneuvering, you will be able to guide the creation of stars, solar systems, and even galaxies.

God Plays Dice is a micro-style game of managing and manipulating probabilities. By collecting and rolling dice you can gain control of cards that have special powers that allow you to better collect and roll dice, and to score victory points. Sometimes you will be at the mercy of the dice, but sometimes the other players will be at the mercy of you.
categories: Card Game, Dice, Print & Play, Science Fiction, Space Exploration
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling

name: Dubai: Rebuild the Ruins
description:
The Great War is now just a distant memory in the minds of all but the eldest among us. Battles led to the splintering of the people living around The Shining City while one faction remained: the Hazimin. The Hazimin have done what they can to keep their still-glistening tower standing tall. However, though their monumental home in the center of the city is still impressive, their numbers are few. Even as new generations grow to power, the ruins of Dubai are at the heart of all conflicts among the factions of the wasteland. With the ruins still standing as a beacon of what once was — and a promise of what could be again — the new leaders of each faction (the Hazimin, the Bahriyyin, the Tayyarin, and the New Badu) have decided it is time to reclaim the city and become the leaders of Dubai.

Power over the city will be decided by the people, and only with that power can one faction establish their dominance. As your faction's leader, it is up to you to turn the ruins of the diamond of the desert into a new home for the people — but your control must outreach that of other factions to ensure that you rebuild the ruins in your image and rule the reformed city of Dubai!

Dubai: Rebuild the Ruins combines a unique thematic flavor with worker placement, tile-laying, and resource management elements in a game set in 2299 for 2-4 players. By using roundels for worker placement, players are constantly engaged in the game with little downtime as turn order is always changing. This allows for multiple player interactions as one player's turn often involves reactions from other players. The setting is additionally unique, but draws closely from the buildings of the modern day city of Dubai. In the end, the faction that has rebuilt the most of the city rules Dubai!
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Set Collection, Tile Placement, Variable Player Powers, Worker Placement

name: The Sands of Sudan
description:
This was a project borne out of nostalgia for the photographs from the old Wargames World and Wargames Illustrated as well stories from various expatriate wargamers who moved to Australia and re-told great stories about fighting the Mahdi with Peter Gilder at the Wargames Holiday Centre.

After gathering information, sheets, original source tables and other files, the rules have been put together as close to the Gilder style of game as possible.

The Umpire plays the part of the Mahdists and their entry, troop type, disposition and general attitude is determined by the situation and random dice. The events cards play the part of creating an additional element of the unknown into every game so that the same scenario can only rarely ever play the same way twice. Mahdists are on larger style crafted bases for ease of movement and each base represents 100 men (scale of 1:10) even though there could be as few as 5 figures on a base if desired.

The Imperials are all played by the gamers. "Us" against the Umpire is great fun!

This is also the perfect game for Solo play.

Organisation is based on five companies to a regiment each company consisting of 12 figures. Once again, you can use 12 or as few figures as you wish as figures are never removed from bases but marked off on an easy to use Roster sheet.

Cavalry work in squadrons and Troops and artillery batteries in sections up.

The game comes with a 44 page gloss laminated booklet and a deck of random event cards. Six blank cards are included so players can tailor events and circumstances to suit your their collections and gaming dispositions.

name: Reclaim Neverland
description:
Reclaim Neverland is a strategy game that takes place in Peter Pan's Neverland that is under siege by four pirate captains.

Reclaim Neverland is unlike other deckbuilding games because of the combination of PvP elements and a limitation to the size of each players built deck. Similar to its predecessor, Reclaim Oz, It is a unique tabletop experience that has the play differently than any other games in the same genre. We have added items to the game as well, these will work as multipliers and bonuses for specific characters!

The game takes place in Neverland, home to famous characters such as Peter Pan, Tinker Bell, and Tiger Lily, but at a time when a new band of pirates, including Captain James Hook, are mounting a siege on the inhabitants. All the great Heroes of Neverland have disappeared, and four Pirates from the Mainland have taken over. While J. M. Barrie may have written a much happier world, this is still the same place, with all the characters and places you know and love—but in a time of great terror. The game has several animals, beasts, and mythos from the original book Peter and Wendy including characters from Little White Bird—it is your task to get the World back to the way it once was, with the characters you collect along the way. If you are able to compile the best deck filling each of the categories (HERO, BRAVE, LOST), you win!

name: 600: il Secolo di Ferro
description:
A card game, set in the Iron Century and created in Italy to be used in school, right after the lessons about the Iron Century (Secolo di Ferro).

Its 103 cards depict five different cultures: Catholics, Reformed, Scientists, Demonic and Pirates.

Card types span from characters (Protagonists and Characters) to Bastions, Objects and Specials. Lots of Attack cards are provided to weaken the enemy cities.

To win, you have to create a city containing figures from all the five cultures.

Played in the classroom, the game entertains the children while helping them remember some key concepts about the Iron Century.

The game has been translated in English and Portuguese by PeterPiers.

P.s. the pre-2015 game prototype featured two additional cultures, Turks and Artists, not ported to the new release.
categories: Card Game, Educational, Fighting, Print & Play
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Set Collection, Take That

name: The Path
description:
Game of Life with an Islamic theme.

Easy rules: The player who collects the most Good Deeds and builds the largest Family wins the game.
Advanced rules: The player who collects the most Good Deeds (in Gold), the best Career, the best Cars. the best House and can completely fill out any sections of the Personal Player Card wins the game.
All these things are marked with collecting special tiles. For getting the different tiles the player has to hit Special fields for collecting, changing or trading the things.
The movement of the pawns is driven by Spinning a Move Spinner.

name: Townsmen
description:
Townsmen is a game for 1 to 4 players where you have to manage a small Town in the Colonial age.

Every turn each player have to play 4 cards and, at the end of their turn they have to replenish their hand with 4 new cards from his deck. Each card provide two different actions to choose from. Some of them give you resources and other give you actions that are used with the personal board to add new cards to your deck or to develop these cards with more powerful cards, etc.....

There are also buildings to build, that give the player new special actions to activate every turn.

name: Fathoms
description:
Setting: The Year is 2078. The world has changed and will not return to it’s previous state. In 2052 Umbratech, the first major corporation to rise from the ashes of the ecological wars of the mid 40’s grew in power and ambition. With their invention of the world’s first Planetary Core Reactor, located on the undersea Mid-Atlantic Ridge, it was hoped that the world would never again rely on non-renewable sources of energy. However, things did not go as planned. With no knowledge of the deepest crusts scientists blindly drilled to reach the intense heat of the Earth’s Core, relying on theoretical data on the makeup of the Earth’s layers. They were wrong, and a rapid reactor failure ensued, allowing the Earth’s mantle to bleed through the crust. Massive continental shift occurred, along with earthquakes and a total disruption of oceanic ecosystems. A new continent emerged from the ridge, born in a matter of months. Midatlantia, as it was called, was both rich in resources and hotly contested. New ocean currents, melted icecaps, and the worldwide destruction of cities launched a new era on the Earth as world powers fought bitterly for the new and old land alike.

This war was known as the Mid-Atlantic War. By 2057 the war was over, and an alliance of the warring states had been formed to share the land. However, shortly after colonization the Mid-Atlantic Alliance ceded from their mother nations and declared independence, causing worldwide uproar. The troubles of creating a new nation were soon soothed by the vast wealth of Midatlantia, and the world was quickly ready to begin trade despite misgivings about the legitimacy of such a nation.

In 2064, the world’s first, large scale underwater research station was created under the mantle of international cooperation. Recognizing that the ocean held untold secrets which would ultimately benefit mankind, the major nations of the world came together to form the International Maritime Collective. Together, they created the International Oceanic Observatory and Research Facility, often referred to as “The Dome”. This underwater facility was built on the floor of the Mariana trench in the Atlantic Ocean, thousands of feet beneath the surface. It has now been operational for fourteen years. Numerous scientific advances have been achieved through its research and thousands of new species have been cataloged and studied, resulting in cures for many diseases and new technologies that improve the lives of people everywhere. But rumour has it that scientists aboard the station have been conducting unauthorized research as well.

Overview: Fathoms is a cooperative adventure game with miniatures in which a group of players fight against hordes of undersea monsters controlled by a game master. Gameplay is designed to pit players against a changing environment as monsters swarm and water pours through hull breaches. Players advance their characters skills and armament by gaining experience. The game can be played in campaign mode in which a series of missions unfold a storyline, or as one-shot scenarios.

Gameplay: Fathoms begins by one player assuming the role of the Fathom Master, while the others pick from a selection of characters. Both the Fathom Master and the other players earn experience points. Players use it advance their character in skills that benefit either themselves or the whole team and to buy equipment. The Fathom Master uses it to unleash increasing terrors upon the players, such as more monsters or events like hull breaches. Players gain experience when they explore, kill monsters or use computer terminals to perform various tasks. This experience may be used between missions or at equipment lockers. The Fathom Master gains experience by damaging players and may spend it on his turn.

The game board functions as a grid and the line of sight rules are relatively simple. Each player receives two actions which may be divided any way they choose. In any order or repetition a player may move, attack or use an item/door/skill. Turn order is determined by rolling for initiative. Each player has 1 miniature which they maneuver through the rooms on the game board. When new rooms are opened, the Fathom Master places units depending on the number of players he opposes. Some of those units are predetermined while other may be bought with experience to add variability. Each round the Fathom Master follows the mission guide to keep the game evolving.

Modes of Play:
Fathoms offers two modes of play: Campaign mode and Scenarios

There are 7 missions in Campaign mode, all of which are meant to be played sequentially as the story unfolds. Scenarios are one-shot missions that represent possible scenarios that could have occurred over the course of the storyline.

Game End: The game ends when players complete either the Campaign storyline or a one-shot Scenario. The game also ends if all Players are killed during a mission. Players that don't work well with others die, quickly.

Unique Elements: What makes Fathoms different than other adventure games is its use of water as an important game element. As the players progress through the game they encounter pools of water and hull breaches that will flood the map room by room. One simple rule guides the flow of water from room to room, making it simple to work with and compelling in the way it changes the battlefield. In water, weapons may become stronger or weaker, some skills may cease to be effective, and monsters grow stronger and more formidable.

Fathoms also has high-ground, which can give tactical advantage whether a room is dry or flooding with water.

name: The Kids vs. The House
description:
You and your friends are tired of having all your great stuff go missing. You know it's that creepy house on the corner, and you have had enough. You are each going to gather a group of friends from the neighborhood and make a mad dash into the house to try to get your items back.

To start The Kids vs. The House, players determine how many items — as few as one and up to twenty — they need to recover from the house. This allows them to customize the length of their game.

You then flip the fist item card over and see how many kid team points you need to have to try to get the item back.

Each player starts with two cards from the Action/Kid deck. This deck contains kids from the neighborhood worth 1-5 points each that you add to your hand to try to build up a team with enough points to retrieve the item. There are also four other types of cards that cause things, do things, and help protect you from the creepy things that can happen in the house:


Chaos cards always go off when drawn. Chaos she is a harsh mistress.
Protection cards are used to prevent or deflect many of the negative events and actions in the game.
Incident cards can be played on other players during your action phase to try to disrupt their chances of acquiring the item.
Trap cards always go off when drawn, with the house apparently trying to defend its ill-gotten gains. Beware the house!


During your turn, you draw a card from the Action/Kid deck. If it doesn't instruct you to play it immediately (traps and chaos cards), then you can put it in your hand. You then have the option to perform an action. If you have a card that is playable (Incident and some Chaos), you can play this on the other players to help yourself or hurt their chances to win.

Turns proceed around the play area until someone has at least as many points in their hand as shown as the target number on the item. Once that minimum is met, they can choose to fold their hand and place it face down. They now cannot be targeted by any incidents, but can be affected by Chaos and Trap cards.

Once a person folds, everyone yet to play in that round draws one card, then everyone reveals their cards to see who has the most points and clams the item.

If this wasn't the final item, shuffle the cards and repeat with the next item. When the final item is claimed, the person with the most points at the end wins.

---
We currently are planning a Kickstarter launch in August 2016

name: Save Our Souls: The Deck De(con)struction Game
description:
In Save Our Souls 2 to 4 players try to evacuate (reduce to 0 cards) their doomed cruise ships (their deck).

Ever since Dominion and the early adopters of the deckbuilding mechanism had been released, the designer mused about a deck de(con)struction game being released just being a matter of time.
Up to now, nobody has implemented this in a way that uses deckbuilding mechanisms and where the sole goal is to empty the deck (Valley of the Kings being very close though).

Rescue cards from your deck, buy action cards to speed up things, be the first to empty the deck (pun intended).

name: Just Dust
description:
Become a God... but without powers!

In Just Dust you are a god without powers in search of Redemption. The only chance you have to redeem yourself is to prosper the people assigned you. You can influence some key-characters that give you instant benefits.

Your goal on the game is to arrive at the end with more followers than your rivals.

Just Dust was inspired to my book: Solo Polvere.

The game is composed 108 cards divided into:

1 card "FAVOUR OF ANCIENT GOD"
4 cards "HEART OF TOWN"
5 cards characters
98 building cards: 40 cards production places (various colours) and 58 cards "RED” places.



The cards are all: characters, structures, resources and money.
The game hasn’t a set number of rounds. The player with the "FAVOUR OF ANCIENT GOD" card starts the game. He choose a character card placing it in front of himself and performs the action with the respective profit.
Then the other players, starting from the left, perform the action without the profit.
When all the players have selected the character and played the actions, the round ends.

Build production places or "RED" places. Get the necessary resources and acquire followers.

The winner is the one who has at the end of the game the highest number of followers.
mechanics: Hand Management, Set Collection, Variable Phase Order

name: Remember Limerick! The War of the Two Kings: Ireland, 1689-1691 – Pro Religione et Libertate
description:
Pro Religione et Libertate (PRL) is an operational level wargame expansion for Red Sash Games' 2010 title Remember Limerick! The latter covers the war between King James II and King William III in Ireland, from 1689-1691. PRL expands the game to cover the Dutch invasion of England in 1688 (a.k.a. the Glorious Revolution) and the fighting in Scotland that took place in parallel with the war in Ireland, 1689-1692.

PRL belongs to Red Sash Games' Lace Wars series of 17th and 18th Century operational wargames and uses the same scales (units are battalions and regiments, map distances are 4 leagues per hex, turns are 3 weeks each).

PRL has scenarios for 2 players. These allow the players to fight the invasion of 1688 and the Scottish campaign. When combined with Remember Limerick! up to 4 people can play. There are 2 campaign scenarios, one starting in 1688 and one in 1689.
categories: Age of Reason, Expansion for Base-game, Pike and Shot, Wargame

name: Guilds and Castles
description:
This game is about a King that wants to build a new castle and the players are the builders competing for the job.
The two Guilds in the game have a dislike for each other , the one being the Merchants Guild and the other the Thieves Guild.
From the merchants guild you can get the building blocks, to build a castle wall, so the King can inspect your works and see if he likes your work to give you the job of building the his castle. The Thieves guild also wants to take the job with their own builders (so later on can have control over the castle) but the Merchants guild refuses to give any request forms for building blocks. So the players can have special action through the game from the Thieves, and while the Thieves are getting paid, with Blocks from the players, they get to build their part of the Castle.

The game is a Midweight euro game with hand management while the players get to compete my bidding and majority controlling, managing the resources they get.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Hand Management, Pattern Building, Set Collection

name: Piat Gin
description:
Piat Gin is a card drafting game with Rummy-like scoring at the end. Players are dealt 6 cards. They keep one, placing face-down in front of them, and then pass two from their hand face-up to the player on their left. This is repeated, keeping one passing two, until they only have three cards left in their hand. During this last hand (you'll have three cards) you'll keep one and only pass one. Once finished players will keep both of these cards to finish their set of cards. All players reveal their hands and begin scoring. The highest scoring hand wins and receives bonus points. Play to a set score, usually 100 points.

Piat Gin is the next game in the series of "alien card games", Konog being the first. Games designed around the premise of a fictional alien race and how they might go about making a game that reflects their culture, biology, ideologies and other aspects of the species. These games are imported and introduced to those of us living in the Core Systems by the explorers and pioneers returning from the frontiers.

The Camenni are a long-lived species, known for extreme patience and sudden bursts of well-coordinated action. Piat Gin is a simple past time, different from the more complex time-consuming games that the elders might take part in (games similar to Chess or Go in which single turns can take years or decades to accomplish). This is not a game that possesses lavish details or ornate components. Piat Gin is carried by Camenni adventurers due to its small size or used to teach children patience and to practice the observation of subtle interactions of others.

The card faces and their features are intentionally kept simple, possessing no complex Camenni script, only differing amounts of circles, triangles, or rhombus (3 suits, numbered 1-6). This is so the game can be taught to most any species that might be encountered (please note that this deck is not resistant to mucus, salivation, persperation, or extremely high body temperatures like standard "outrider" decks). Camenni will drag a game of Piat Gin on for hours and even days when playing with each other. Of course, we don't have that luxury and play a round in a few minutes.

name: All Are Brothers: Solferino, 1859
description:
All Are Brothers: Solferino, 1859 simulates the decisive battle of the Second Italian War of Independence at the Brigade-level, with some additional Regimental-size and smaller detachments included. National and corps-level leaders are represented, on a map at 500 meters per hex, with 1-hour turns. Five scenarios are included: three that separately cover the north, central, and southern sectors of the battle, as well as a combined full battle scenario, along with a small introductory scneario. The combined scenario is suitable for up to four players (France, Sardinia-Piedmont, Austrian 1st Army, and Austrian 2nd Army).

The battle itself was a grinding slugfest often described as a "soldier's battle" - a deliberate slight to the often uninspired leadership of the generals and a tribute to an allied victory gained only at the tip of the bayonet. Villagers in the surrounding region would do their best in the days after to treat the myriad wounded, and answer as to why Austrians, Hungarians, Czechs, Serbs, and Slovaks were treated as well as the Italians: "Tutti fratelli" (All are brothers). The battle pits two Austrian armies against the combined forces of France and Sardinia-Piedmont, and features the full panoply of colorful period units - Jagers and Grenzers, massed cavalry divisions of all types, Bersaglieri, French Imperial Guard, and the French African Zouaves and Turcos. Advances in infantry and artillery firepower would soon make the tactics of the time obsolete, and the carnage at Solferino reflected the start of this paradigm shift, soon to be highlighted bloodily by the Austro-Prussian and Franco-Prussian wars.

This treatment of Solferino features an adaptation of Hermann Luttmann’s Blind Swords system (At Any Cost, Hammerin' Sickles, Stonewall's Sword) as the core ruleset. The system is heavy on unpredictability and fog of war due to the chit pull mechanic. The chit pull mechanic also very much aids in solitaire play, as does variable activation rules and reinforcement tables.
