Thee colours of the card show the activated neighborhoods and, subsequently, the active players.The player/s who own business in the neighbourhood indicated by the colour of the current year is defined active and can perform the
action chosen by the current player.

Each player gains VP starting new business in a neighborhoods and selling the barrels.

Victory can be achieved in 2 different ways: a player catches the next player on his left on the VP track and at the end of the 12th turn (year) determining who has scored the most VPs.

—description from the designer

name: DreadBall: Glambek Ghosts Ada-Lorana Team
description:
Outside the Co-Prosperity Sphere, the Ada-Lorana are arbiters of justice. They will not break rules; at least not those set by the DGB, but the rules of physics are another matter entirely. They have the ability to phase through solid objects, which takes some serious getting-used-to for their opponents!

—description from the team card
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Sports
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: DreadBall: Sulentic Shards Crystallan Team
description:
The Sulentic Shards were one of the first Crystallan Dreadball teams, putting their natural abilities and talents to good use on the neodurium and enabling them to live a more settled life. Their unique physical characteristics mean that when all of their energies are aligned few teams can match them. When they are not, then there is always the option of just smashing down anyone who gets in their way.

—description from the team card
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Sports
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Legends of the Untamed West: Sunset at Silver Creek
description:
You are in Nevada, the year is 1895. Rumors of foul play in the mining town of Silver Creek have led the local marshall to hire you to investigate. With the amount of money available in town, and with the remote location of the town, you would hardly be surprised that something is afoot. But you have little to go on, save the accidental drowning death of a local manager, and the word that witnesses are missing...

Sunset at Silver Creek is a complete programmed adventure set in the American West for solitaire or group play. The game includes an adventure booklet, game rules and playing pieces used to resolve the gun fights fought on the game map (also included). It is the second in the Legends of the Untamed West series which uses a similar game system to Dark City Games' Legends of the Ancient World, which is based on the Fantasy Trip game system.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Hexagon Grid, Role Playing

name: Teenage Morphing Superheroes
description:
The peaceful school day was interrupted, yet again, with another Super Monster spotted marching toward our city! Of course, only the team of 5 Teenage Morphing Superheroes can stand on its way! They must try to stop the Monster before it reaches the city and unleash the devastation upon its innocent population!

Each round a card with the monster attack will be revealed. Players will secretly play cards in order to try to defend from Monster attacks. Players are not allowed to say what cards they are playing. When all cards are revealed, collectively they must beat the correct type of attack that the monster is threatening with.

Instead of fighting, players may play "selfie" cards. That way, a player is slacking in combat but will earn him a victory point. At the end of the game, the player with greatest popularity on social networks is the winner of the game, or, if Super Monster reaches the city, all players lose.

This is a semi-coop game, where players must balance between fighting monster (for greater good) or be selfish and collect victory points, and try to persuade others that "they really need to beat the monster this time".

name: Sandstorm:  World War II in North Africa
description:
Sandstorm is a 2-player, card driven, hex and counter format game on the North African campaign. The map covers the area from approximately el Algheila in the west to just east of el Alamein in the east, aka 'the Western Desert'. The time period allows a start when the Italians invade Egypt in September, 1940, and ends December, 1942, when the Axis were driven out of Cyrenaica. The game has 2 months turns and use larger counters, 5/8th of inch, a full campaign should take between 10 to 14 hours.

Sandstorm is a 2-player game on the North African campaign with the recommendation to begin play when the German intervened in March 1941. However, one may start as early as September, 1940; albeit subject to Mussolini’s directive to invade Egypt, amongst other starting dates. The campaign game ends when the Axis were driven out of the ‘western desert,’ Cyrenaica and Egypt, December, 1942; other ending date may be selected. Players assume the role of the ground commanders trying to outperform their historical counterparts with the focus on the operational aspects. You plan and execute the sweeping maneuverers or head-first assaults. You have to make some of the same choices, do you press ahead in the hopes of a quick victory or pause to establish your line of supply?
You will be bedeviled by the same problems, supply, the need to rest and refit, terrain, and, sometimes, your own superiors. Victory is achieved by eliminating the other player’s units from the region, delaying the opponent’s advance, or inflicting more casualties and taking few casualties than historically occurred.

A design aspect is toward playability in a reasonable table space within a manageable time commitment. The game map is 22” by 48,” at a scale of 12.5 miles or 20 kilometers per hex and encompasses the territory from the border between Cyrenaica and Tripolitania, Libya, in the west to just east of el Algheila, near the outskirts of Alexandria. Each game turn represents 2 months of calendar time. Unit sizes are generally regiments for the Axis and brigades for the Allies. An 11 turn campaign, from Mar/Apr 41 to Dec 41, game takes between 8 to 12 hours.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Events, Hexagon Grid, Movement Points, Ratio / Combat Results Table, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Victory Points as a Resource, Zone of Control

name: The Coldest Winter
description:
The Coldest Winter is a card-driven block wargame about the military conflict between the Soviet Union and Finland between November 1939 and March 1940. The conflict is better known as the Winter War as it happened during an extraordinarily cold winter.

The game emphasizes military operations on a strategic level using block game pieces to obscure the information on the block labels to simulate the fog of war.

The game also has a political layer to reproduce the international atmosphere as the eyes of the world were fixed on the war. Both nations must keep an eye on their Morale status as if it falters, it may hinder their number of actions per turn.

In addition, Finland has to manage its dwindling resources as it was not prepared for a full scale Soviet offensive after just a few decades after the nation gained its independence and fought a civil war. The Soviet military on the other hand was not prepared to encounter such fierce resistance and to fight in such harsh weather and terrain. The Soviet Union has to reform its military to readjust to these matters.

The game revolves around two unique 45 card command decks, one for each player. Each command card has an event and command point value to activate units and perform strategic actions. Both players also have two special unique decks of 5 cards to represent the international support for Finland and the reformed military approach for the Soviet Union. Both special decks contain what-if scenarios in addition to historical course of events.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Secret Unit Deployment

name: The Fort of Gold
description:
The Fort of Gold (金の砦) is a solitaire game in which you take on the role of a sorcerer manipulating mana to collect seven treasures. There is one deck of treasures and one of magical spirits. Spirits and treasures both have a set of three elemental symbols, where each symbol can be one of earth, air, fire, or water. In order to collect a treasure you need to create a set of one or more spirits that can match with all the elements on the treasure.

However, you may not be able to collect any of the treasures initially exposed. In that case you can swap the exposed treasures or peek at and rearrange the deck, but these both require more demanding combinations of elements.

You win if you can get all seven treasures, but you lose if you're stuck without any legal actions. Can you activate all the spirits before your mana runs out?

name: Tanto Cuore: Lapis Aurora
description:
Promo card originally released with a calendar. It was later given out as tournament prizes.
During your turn this maid allows you to change one maid that you play's Servings or Employments into Love or Draws.

This is PR38.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management

name: Fallen Frontiers: The Battle of Hextrom VI
description:
The Fallen Frontiers 2nd edition starter box set.

The battle for Hextrom VI presents a initiation skirmish to get you familiarized with the Fallen Frontiers game system where the Riff must eliminate the Ares resistance to capture an important strategic point. From here you can extend your armies and play games with a greater number of miniatures.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Action Points, Action Queue, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling

name: Ultra Modern Army Lists and Organisations Volume 1
description:
A revised edition of Ultra Modern Army Lists and Organisations to fully take account of the use of Challenger rules as well as still being suitable for WRGs rules.

Introduces new equipment since the previous edition.

This edition concentrates on European based armies:
The Central Front, NATO, WARPAC, European Neutrals.
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Wargame

name: Top Dog Card Game
description:
Top Dog is a fun and competitive card game for social interactions with family members and friends of all ages. Be the first player to get rid of all your cards by outplaying your opponents. Use combinations of dogs and power dogs to empty your hand first. Copy Cats can complete a dog stack and clear the Dogpile on any turn while Dog Catchers can clear the Dogpile and send them running to dog pound on your turn. Use Copy Cats and Dog Catchers wisely to outwit and defeat your opponents.

Players will have dog cards, which they may play in combinations, and Power Dogs, which they may also play in combinations. There are also Copy Cats, which are essentially wild cards and Dog Catchers, which immediately send all dogs to the Dog Pound, which is where all the cards that were completed from the Dogpile go. The cards in the Dog Pound will not be used until the round is over and a new round begins.
The first player places a card or combinations of cards on the Dogpile, which is the pile of played cards in the middle of the table. Play then continues to the left. During your turn, you can play a card or a combination of cards that are of higher value than the last played. However, your turn can be taken away if a Completion occurs by another player before the player whose turn it is can play a card. A completion occurs when there are 4 of the same type of cards on the Dogpile. Completions can be played out of turn regardless of how many cards are being played on the Dogpile. The same type of cards can be stacked to increase the value of the Dogpile. For example, you can Stack a single card on a double if they are of the same type. If a player can not play on the Dogpile, that player has to draw from the Dog House (Draw Deck) until they can play.

The first person to run out of cards in the round wins the round, and the first person to win 3 rounds is the Top Dog.

—description from the designer

name: Muffins Among Us: Food Truck Edition
description:
The Food Truck edition contains all of the deceit and trickery from the original Muffins Among Us game, but without all the hoopla! We've left all of the characters, tokens, and missions in the Bakery and set off on our truck for countless adventures for you and all of your friends.

This version of the game is simplified, yet retains all of the strategy and secrecy of the full version and is perfect for a family of 4, or a party up to 15! It is also completely mobile, fitting in your pocket, and can be played in a large open room with no table, or even in a bus or other vehicle.

The Food Truck Edition also includes 4 new secret identities including The Baker, The Baker's son, The Bagel, and the Cat!

—description from the designer

name: Dust 1947: Luftwaffe Fallschirm RSO Flak/Laserkanone/Pak 40
description:
The Raupenschlepper Ost is a dedicated light and airdrop vehicle in service with the Luftwaffe ground forces. Thanks to its weight, it can be parachuted along with the airborne troops, offering them a much needed fire support during the first phase of an operation. This reference allows you to field one of three variants: an antiaircraft version, an antitank version with antitank gun and an antitank version with laser gun. All crews on the pictures are included.

This item comes with three Dust 1947 Unit Cards, one for each variant, for the Luftwaffe Faction of the Axis Bloc. Like all regular Dust 1947 miniatures, it comes already assembled and primed. It's ready for the battlefield, or for painting, as you wish! You can directly paint over on it, since the priming serves as an undercoat and is compatible with any type of paint.

—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Dust 1947: Gregor The Defector
description:
Once part of the BlutKreuz Korps, he has now joined the ranks of the Mercenaries. A true war machine, Gregor is a beast in Close Combat and at longer range as well! He can be played with any army in the World of Dust and will be a great addition to any force!

This reference comes with two Dust 1947 unit cards, one for the Mercenaries and one for the BlutKreuz Korps. Like all regular Dust 1947 miniatures, it comes already assembled and primed. It's ready for the battlefield, or for painting, as you wish! You can directly paint over on it, since the priming serves as an undercoat and is compatible with any type of paint.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Dust 1947: Loki / Loth (Trop) PanzerKampfLäufer II-C/F
description:
The Loki is probably one of the deadliest antiaircraft walker in existence. Thanks to its improved open chassis, it can now be found all over the world, anywhere the Axis fights.
The Loth variant is an Engineer and Mechanic walker, always useful to help other walkers get out of dire situations. It is also very common wherever Axis forces are present.
This box will allow you to field one of these two variants.

This item comes with two Dust 1947 Unit Cards, for the NDAK Faction of the Axis Bloc. Like all regular Dust 1947 miniatures, it comes already assembled and primed. It's ready for the battlefield, or for painting, as you wish! You can directly paint over on it, since the priming serves as an undercoat and is compatible with any type of paint.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Dust 1947: Natalya/Nadya/Natasha
description:
KV-47 walkers are the most common within the large armies of the SSU: robust, reliable and tough, they can be equipped with a variety of weapons, adapted for each mission. The Natasha has two grenade launchers, efficient against infantry and light vehicles. The Nadya can melt anything thanks to its two flamethrowers and the Natalya shreds everything fool enough to get in range! These three walkers can be transported by a specialized helicopter. This reference allows you to field one of these three variants.

This reference comes with three Dust 1947 unit cards, one per variant, all for the SSU Bloc. Like all regular Dust 1947 miniatures, it comes already assembled and primed. It's ready for the battlefield, or for painting, as you wish! You can directly paint over on it, since the priming serves as an undercoat and is compatible with any type of paint.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Thievestown
description:
Become the Guild Master of your own Thieves Guild! Players will recruit bandits for their cause to pilfer, plunder, and rob. Work the black market to obtain valuable loot and collect gold to prove you're the best guild master of all. But watch out - you're not the only guild in the city. Add some mayhem to your mischief by wheeling and dealing with rival guilds as you try to secure your place in infamy.

Objective:
Be the guild with the most treasure.

Game Ends:
After four rounds or once the town has been robbed completely of its money.

Game Play: Each round consists of three phases.

Players secretly determines where their guild members will be sent.
Buying from the black market, hiring new guild members, and robbing buildings. Players will have to decide when and if they will work together and how to divvy up the loot.
Upkeep


Mechanics:
Every character has a combination of lock picking skills(might, magic, and mechanical) based on their level. Roll the dice for each character to break into buildings and retrieve the treasure. But don't take too many thieves as alarm dice are rolled for each figure at the location. If other guilds are present, then you'll have to decide if you want to work together and how you'll split the treasure, or go it alone. Table talk is highly encouraged.
mechanics: Action Queue, Dice Rolling, Die Icon Resolution, Simultaneous Action Selection, Take That

name: Poteen
description:
In Poteen collect a set of each Step Cards (Barley, Malting, Brewing) to exchange for a Poteen Barrel card. Along the way, avoid Garda Siochana Cards and resolve any Event Cards that appear. Be the first player to collect 3 Poteen Barrel Cards (3-4 players) or 5 Poteen Barrel Cards (2 players) and you win.

—description from the publisher

name: 63:  The Board Game
description:
While traveling through the remotest part of the Himalayan Mountains, Michael Cullen and Ian Carson were introduced to a game of chance and strategy that has been played down through the ages by those rugged souls that inhabit a region where few would survive.

It is with great pride and reverence that we bring back this jewel for you and yours to enjoy. A true game of strategy that will add excitement to any festive gathering.

The game of 63 has its origins in Bhutan, the Land of the Thunder Dragon. This ancient kingdom, nestled between Tibet, India and Nepal, is a place out of time where traditional life thrives in the shadow of the world's greatest mountain range. Deep in the isolated Himalayan Mountains, it is not uncommon for the mountain village men to huddle together to play this game.

They mark out 63 spots using twigs forming a roughly circular playing area. Each player gathers their own set of distinctive tokens from what's available around them. They use blades of grass, plant stems, stones and sticks of different sizes and anything else they can easily find.

The dice are made from yak bone. Each player takes their turn, shaking the dice in a small hardened leather bowl and slamming it down in the centre of the board. The game is played with great enthusiasm and often the outcomes are gambled on. It is a timeless game of opportunity, luck, and strategy from one of the last timeless places left on Earth.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Fill in the Game
description:
Fill in the Game is the fill in the blank party game! Challenge other players to act out a scene or perform stunts using the prompt found on the Challenge Card. Then you fill in the blank to add a twist! They get points if they succeed, but if they fail you draw a Game Changer which can be good for you, bad for them, or affect the whole table! Fill in the Game can be family-friendly or not, depending on your group, and will be different every time you play!

Fill in the Game contents:
42 Challenge Cards: Each card contains 2 Challenges with a blank.
18 Game Changers: Consequences for failing, refusing, or giving up early.
5 Stunt Cards: They might be used based on their letter, number, color, or for stunts like throwing them.
2 double-sided Instructions cards.

There's also a FREE Companion App at FillintheGame.com with idea generators and timers!

INSTRUCTIONS:

Shuffle the Challenges and Game Changers separately and place them in the center. Set the Stunt Cards to the side. Pick a player to go first.

On Your Turn:
Draw a Challenge, but don't reveal it to anyone. Choose another player and ask "top or bottom?". Read their choice out loud and fill in the blank with anything that's safe and possible. If it's a Rule, see below. Announce any notes in italics, the time in the top left, and the point value in the top right.

If They Chose a Rule (-1pt):
It applies to all other players except you. Place it in front of you separate from your scored Challenges. Your turn is over. The first player you catch not following the Rule scores it as -1pt and the Rule ends. If you catch more than one player, you choose!

Challenge Point Values:
1pt cards can't be failed as long as they're attempted.
2pt cards have a way to fail, many by laughing.
3pt cards are the hardest, involving a time limit or a physical challenge.

Stunt Cards:
Some Challenges may use Stunt cards as numbers, colors, letters, or to perform stunts.

Challenge Timing:
Times shown are the minimum time for the Challenge unless specified as a time limit. Cards with an "infinite" symbol are not timed and might even continue during other players' turns (end your turn as appropriate).

If They Complete the Challenge:
Place it in front of them with that Challenge at the top to keep track of their points. Your turn is over.

If They Fail, Refuse, or Give Up Early:
Discard the Challenge. You draw a Game Changer and follow it. It could be good for you, bad for them, or affect the whole table! Don't draw a Game Changer when a player fails a Rule. Discard completed Game Changers. Your turn is over.

After Your Turn is Over:
The player to your left draws a Challenge and play continues until someone scores enough to win.

Winning:
Small groups (3-5) players play to 10pts, and larger groups play to 5pts, or pick your own point goal! House rules are welcome!

name: Mini WWII: Total War
description:
"Mini WWII: Total War" is the first expansion of Mini WWII. In "Total War", you have new units, technologies, and events to simulate the war.

Bombers and submarines can attack your enemy strategy cards, defend your army and navy, and award you extra VPs. You also have new technologies to upgrade your bombing and raiding abilities and the new intelligence event lets you steal technologies from your opponent.

-description from designer
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Hand Management

name: S.W.A.T.: Hostage Rescue
description:
On September 25th 2020, the domestic terrorist group known as “The Watchers” kidnapped a diplomat’s wife and is holding her ransom. They demand the release of several of their members from prison before they let her go. An informant has told the authorities where she is located and the FBI’s Special Weapons and Tactics team has been ordered to rescue her and bring the terrorists to justice. Little do they know, but the media has tipped off the terrorists and they have a surprise waiting for the S.W.A.T. Team.

In this game, the terrorists setup by placing the hostage in a building with two guards. They then write down where their hidden sniper and mine will be placed. After this, they roll to see how many terrorist rifleman they will have and place them on the map. The sniper is a hidden unit and is not placed on the map until he fires or a unit moves adjacent to him.

The S.W.A.T. forces initially enter in truck from the West and East end of the map. During their first turn one of their trucks will run over the hidden mine and the truck will be destroyed and the occupants must roll saves to see if they survive. The S.W.A.T. forces have one additional unit that can enter on any turn in a helicopter. If the helicopter lands adjacent to any terrorist unit (including the hidden sniper) it will be shot down.

During the game, the S.W.A.T. forces will battle the terrorists and possibly try to arrest some of them. Arrest attempts are dangerous and the S.W.A.T. unit can be killed in the process. Once the S.W.A.T. team eliminates any terrorists guards holding the hostage, they can move in and take control of her. They then need to transport her off map either on foot, in a truck or with the helicopter.

The game ends when either the hostage is rescued or all the S.W.A.T. team members are killed. Victory points are then calculated to see which side won and what level of victory they achieved.

This game is designed for 2 players, but plays fairly well solitaire. Most games last around 25 minutes.

—description from the designer

name: Morse Thieves
description:
In this cooperative game, players belong to a gang of outlaws that wants to rob a train before it reaches the mountain tunnel. In order to do so, each outlaw must bring three items needed for the robbery. To keep their dastardly plan a secret, however, the gang can only communicate with each other via Morse Code.

Each player receives three item cards; these are the items that they need to bring to the gang's hideout. The train's initial distance to the tunnel is determined by the sum value of all players' cards.

During their turn, each player rolls the four 'transmission' dice, using the resulting Morse Code dot/dash combination to form one or more letters of items on the map. Once an item's word has been spelt, any player needing that item can go to that locale and take it, immediately gaining its benefit.

Whenever a player moves from one locale to another on the map, or is unable to use all four of the transmission dice, the train moves one click closer to the tunnel. If the odometer on the train reaches zero before all the outlaws arrive in the hideout with their three items, it escapes! The gang also has to contend with a troublesome Sheriff, who puts outlaws in jail, and Indians who will barter for items before you can get them!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Pick-up and Deliver, Point to Point Movement, Set Collection, Variable Player Powers

name: Fourth Millennium
description:
In the year 2388, a group of university students working in the Tycho Crater settlement, New Pottsdam, invent the long-desired technology of a Faster Than Light (FTL) propulsion system. (In this case, an Alcubierre design.) Mankind expands outward in every direction, for 3000 light years, in the next 700 years.

It is now the year 3000 AD, and after a little less than 700 years of FTL technology, man has created a modest sphere of inhabited systems some 6000 light years in diameter, and a collective population nearing 1 trillion souls. Many, many systems containing habitable worlds still remain to be explored and colonized within that sphere, yet the expansion relentlessly continues. A few, planet-bound sapient races have been found, but no other race with space travel (much less FTL capability) has yet to be revealed.

But the Milky Way galaxy is a vast expanse of hundreds of billions of stars, and despite centuries of FTL drives, man has still only seen the smallest fraction of a single percentage point of those star systems.

Much, much more lies out there, not the least of which is other, star-faring races. And of those, some are hopefully friendly and open-armed (in some cases, figuratively), some likely paranoid beyond reason, some simply convinced that any species other than their own must be eradicated, but most will likely fall in various places across the spectrum of possibilities. The diplomatic skills of man will be sorely tested, as may his ability and will to wage interstellar warfare.

Fourth Millennium is a 4X game for 1 to 6 players, set on a map of the entire Milky Way galaxy – 100,000 light years in diameter – where each player will choose their own path in attempting to carve out the biggest and best empire, encountering a variety of 36, possible alien races, each with its own unique attributes, attitude, and aspirations, not to mention the empires being built by the other players.

Staying relevant technologically will prove a challenge. Some alien races you encounter may be more advanced than you…and not happy about your presence on their doorstep. Indeed, you may even need to ally with other players in order to whittle down a common threat.

And during your explorations, you may find multiple artifacts, left behind by a long-gone race. They are key to understanding new technologies and improving you overall civilization. But be forewarned. Those who left behind these artifacts - which we call "The Andromedans" - are still observing, may decide to intervene, and if so, with the sole intent of destroying all, competing star-faring races.

—description from the designer

name: 太陽と月の王国 (Taiyo to Tsuki no Oukoku)
description:
太陽と月の王国 (Taiyo to Tsuki no Oukoku), roughly translated as Kingdom of the Sun and the Moon, is a climbing game where there will be one loser among the players.

The game uses a pyramid deck of cards (one 1, two 2s,..., ten 10s) and a player's "hand" of cards is split between cards that are dealt to a traditional hand, and cards that form a pyramid in front of each player. This pyramid is face down, except for the front row, and players can choose to play cards from their hand, their pyramid, or a combination.

Players can play the same rank as a previous player, and if 4 of the same rank have been played, the round ends immediately, with the current player winning that round and the ranks of cards reversing.

Rounds continue until only 1 player has cards left in hand; that player loses 1 life. Once 1 player has lost both of their lives, the game ends, and they lose.

name: Snerz
description:
Snerz is a tactical game of sailing missions and islands’ exploration. Players will be skilled ship captains sailing the unknown water of the wavy sea. Each player tries to become the most glorious one by accomplishing missions, obtaining money and equipment cards, recruiting the crew and enlarging the vessel. Other actions as trading, exploring new islands and plundering other captains, can be accomplished to get more power. By doing so, and by attacking other players, the captain obtains “fame points”, which eventually lead to victory and eternal glory.

Thanks to the 11 mixable components, each board will be different from the other. The panel combinations are more than 30 mln, allowing the best gaming experience. By merging the components the “game world”, with islands and seas, gets its shape.

At the beginning of the game, each glorious sailor gets a basic ship and an unskilled crew. To each one is randomly given a specific ability as well as the ship details. These are: speed (how far can this vessel go), maneuverability (crew members needed to move), holds (how many goods can the ship carry), cannons (to attack other ships). Finally there are 5 seats for the brave crew.

Before each round, the first player draws a “wind card” out. This card decides the direction of the active flows. Moreover, it outlines the goods’ productions sites, events taking place in inhabited islands and prices’ variations. Each player’s turn consists of two actions happening on inhabited islands. Those activities need to be chosen among: simple movement, entering the pub to recruit the squad, selling goods or buying a ship part. “Free actions” (healing, fixing, loading goods and one attack) are allowed as well on these islands. While, the only action allowed on an uninhabited island is the sole exploration.

The sea is calm, are you now ready to sail?

—description from the designer
mechanics: Action Points, Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Hexagon Grid, Modular Board, Open Drafting, Pick-up and Deliver, Point to Point Movement, Variable Phase Order, Variable Player Powers

name: Tragedy of the Commons
description:
Tragedy of the Commons is a relatively simple on the surface. There is a 5x5 grid of numbers, and you and each other player must choose five of those numbers. If nobody else picked the number you chose, then you score that many points. If someone else did choose your number, you get no points for that choice. The strategy of the game is trying to figure out what other people will pick. Tragedy of the Commons comes with several grids and variants that alter the game in small but significant ways, and can be played in a few minutes or an hour depending on how many rounds you want to play.

—description from the publisher

name: Of Stone & Wood
description:
Of Stone and Wood is a quick, light, 2-player strategy game that takes 5 minutes to learn and 5-10 minutes to play enabling a "best of 3" competition to be easily played at lunch.

Players are moving their pieces, swapping for adjacent opposition or mercenary pieces, or jumping adjacent pieces in order to form a line of 5 of their pieces, but be careful because the swinging loyalty of the mercenaries makes them just as useful to your opponent as they are to you.

—description from the designer

name: Trudvang Legends: Wildland
description: Wildland is an expansion in which a brand new campaign, with 10+ stories, covers the development of the political tensions and the infestation of enemies and creatures. Form allegiances with new barbaric heroes, choose your place in the dispute, and decide the destiny of the Wildland.

name: Callsign Taranis
description:
15mm Scale Skirmish Wargaming

Wargame expansion rules for use with 15mm miniatures and models. An enjoyable playing experience set in a space opera setting unlike any other. Patrol Angis is a skirmish level wargame and with Callsign Taranis you can move from the low intensity infantry focused warfare of the core game which was your starting point in this universe to something a bit larger and multi faceted too. Make use of vehicles from the humble Adder to the supporting Mullo and of course the mighty Taranis super heavy main battle tank. Introduce flying vehicles, hurwent energy shields, buildings, drones and mecha too. Play solo or with two or more players with games featuring one Platoon (22 Miniatures or several vehicles) a side up to four or even six Platoons a side (100 or more miniatures or a dozen vehicles) with smaller games taking less than an hour to play out. In Callsign Taranis you still choose to play as either the Prydian Army or in the employ of Canlaster or Yordan or any number of lesser rebel Marcher Barons all vying for the throne. This includes playing as a “Conda” or professional mercenary too for any side. Callsign Taranis contains all the rules you need to make use of vehicles and structures in other titles in the series.

In this book you will find the expansion rules covering the use of Vehicles in play as well as Structures and other bolt on mechanics. There are also game statistics for the vehicles of the Prydian Civil War and additional skills, equipment and items for your troops. Following on from Patrol Angis is part two of the Prydian Civil War background. Also in this book is the Support Phase and the Between Games development of your forces. Rules for how to play larger games of Patrol Angis and how to generate random terrain. A bolt on section for Building your Forces with Vehicle and Mixed platoons. This and more all in a packed sixty four pages!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: The Khanate Return
description:
15mm Scale Skirmish Wargaming - Army Book

Welcome to a Forces and Setting Title for Patrol Angis. A new setting and forces with statistics and rules for use with 15mm miniatures and models from The Ion Age.

An enjoyable playing experience in a space opera setting unlike any other. This Army Book brings you to the Camarthen star system for a desperate campaign for possession of a planet upon which sits an alien Matter Gateway. Now that it is switched on the gateway has brought a mythical enemy of Humanity back to reality from far across the galaxy; The Shia Khan Empire. Making use of the Patrol Angis rule book for skirmishes and the Callsign Taranis expansion book for larger games you can now add the Khanate Empire and also Planetary Defence Forces to your games. Read all about the tragic fate of Camarthen Prime and the start of the second Khanate War as a world burns.

You can then create and assemble your own Tesserans and Ordos (platoons) along with vehicles and more for the Khanate with armoury and army lists. Then consult army lists for the Planetary Militias to do the same with Troop Types, Armour, Weapons and platoon composition guides. There are also advanced rules for both new armies covering Nebula Charges, Humascare,and Robotic Infantry among other skills and equipment. The book ends with three small scenarios of varying complexity for new and experienced players. This Army Book joins up with other titles expanding the forces and the universe of The Ion Age. Put forces from a half dozen miniatures to more than a hundred including vehicles into play. Fight for victory on Camarthen Prime or take your fight elsewhere in the Prydian Precinct.

—description from the publisher

name: Gobble-Ins!
description:
Gobble-Ins is a 2-4 player "treasure-eating" game set in a fantasy world filled with spoiled heroes and hungry goblins who eat all their unwanted treasure.

Players will control one of four different goblin characters who inhabit Loot's Abandon, a deep treasure dumping hole in the center of a bustling port town where all the unwanted valuables of adventurers near and far offload their old gear. These goblins have adapted their diets to be able to consume the armor, weaponry, and trinkets that are unknowingly tossed to them, and as such, gain powerful abilities from them!

Each turn, players will move their goblins across the board, attempting to reach treasure tokens that tumble down the four corners of the game board each turn following a specific colored path. The colored path that token will follow is determined by a tumble path card that is played the second a new treasure appears on the game board. Players will attempt to pick up those treasure tokens to obtain treasure cards that imbue them with special powers while they are held in their goblin's stomach. These treasures can be turned in for points to be added up at the end of the game, but hanging onto certain treasures can be helpful as you lose their abilities once they've been removed from your stomach.

More treasure cards are pulled from the deck and treasure tokens will continue to move across the board until all the tumble path cards have been discarded or made inactive. Once this happens, players will add up the value of all the treasure cards they've stashed, as well as any remaining Vomit Tokens (the goblin's currency), and whoever has the most points is the winner!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Variable Phase Order, Variable Player Powers

name: Warhammer: Age of Sigmar – Looncurse
description:
Looncurse is a new battlebox that pits nature’s defenders against some of the Mortal Realms most determined despoilers. Inside, you’ll find two forces of Citadel miniatures, including two models that are only available in this set – the Loonboss on Giant Cave Squig, and a brand-new Sylvaneth Hero, the Arch-Revenant.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Variable Phase Order, Variable Player Powers

name: Steel & Steed: A Wargaming Ruleset for Knights at Tournament
description:
My Lords and Ladies, welcome to the world of Steel & Steed.

Within this book you will find the rules to help you create a knightly tournament worthy of a noble such as yourself. It is here that you will be given the tools to create one day competitions, large events testing the skill and merit of the bravest of knights or even run an ongoing campaign that will allow you to grow your house and become the envy of all the kingdoms across the land. Sharpen your blade and ready your steed, honor and glory are yours for the taking!

Inside the rulebook you will find:


112 pages of wargaming content for Knights at Tournament.
Rules for Jousting, Mounted Combat, Foot Combat, Grand Melee and Archery.
Rules for creating your own custom Knight.
An armory containing different weapons, lances, bows and armor that can be used to outfit your knight exactly how you see fit for any given occasion.
Four different breeds of horses with their own skills and abilities so your Knight can truly have his trusted steed when he rides off to tournament.
A detailed campaign system that allows players to gain fame an fortune in the name of their House or even take to the road alone as a Freelance knight fighting for only coin and personal glory.


And so much more…

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Simulation, Variable Player Powers

name: Moonstone: Tumbledown Street Troupe Box
description:
This troupe box includes 3 new heroes of Commonwealth fraction.
This miniatures are made in fine quality resin. Every miniature requires assembly.

Quack is a human wizard and cleric. He can heal the allies and blind or weak enemy units.
Fritz is a human mercenary that could devastate enemy lines by his great sword and throw away some enemy units.
Agatha - human tavern lady that could support allied units and use concealed dagger against the enemies.

—description from the publisher (translated)
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Humor, Miniatures
mechanics: Action Points, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Rock-Paper-Scissors

name: Dragons: Peasants, Black Cat and Steed Promo Cards
description:
Three new cards you can add to the game, distributed by the publisher.

The Peasants: Count as 3 sheep or 3 cows when counting animals.
The Black Cat: Double your gold coins.
The Steed: Allows you to complete a knight set containing at least one piece of equipment.


—user summary
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy
mechanics: Open Drafting, Push Your Luck, Set Collection

name: Ferman: Sultan's Decree
description:
Following the conquest of Constantinople, the city was in a state of disrepair. The Sultan wanted to restore the city and exceed its former glory as a metropolis. But he couldn’t do it alone. He needed help from the prominent merchants of the Ottoman Empire.

In Ferman, you get to play these merchants and have a chance to be the one to gain Sultan’s favor. He will task you to repair the existing infrastructure, construct new buildings and help those in need. Manage your resources and complete these Quests to get Coins, but be careful! Fermans have the potential to alter the course of the game significantly.

Ferman is a fast-paced economic strategy game with worker placement elements for 3-6 players .The game takes around 30-60 minutes to complete. Aim of the game is to be the first one to get 11 Coins. Coins will primarily be earned through quests, which will require resources such as Silk and Stone. Players will need to compete amongst themselves to gather such resources, considering their supply is limited and they have one action per turn. Excess resources can be traded at the Docks, or could be turned into Coins at the Grand Bazaar.

Heed the call of Sultan, and be the glorious merchant that restores Constantinople to new heights!

—description from the publisher

name: Dr. Frankenstein: Rise of the Monster
description:
Dr. Frankenstein: Rise of the Monster is a print-and-play game designed for 2-4 players, ages 12 and up, and takes about an hour to play.

In Dr. Frankenstein: Rise of the Monster, you are a mad scientist on the brink of a momentous discovery. Will you be the first of your peers to bring your monstrous creation to life? Dig up body parts from the village graveyard, buy items from the workshop, and gather the resources you need to finish your work and become the greatest scientific mind of the age. With your faithful henchman at your side, anything is possible. But beware! The villagers are becoming restless. It’s only a matter of time before they form an angry mob and head for your castle—and that’s sure to send your monster into an angry rampage through the village.

Dr. Frankenstein: Rise of the Monster is a hierarchical worker placement game. Through strategic placement of your pawns, sometimes blocking other players or bumping them to adjacent locations, you collect the resources and body parts needed to bring your monster to life. Once alive, your monster is an additional worker which you may place to gain resources or sacrifice on a rampage through the village to score additional victory points. Players must take care to manage the anger of the villagers by controlling the mob meter, or else the villagers might riot. The burgomeister pawn adds a unique element of placement control and timing, though his loyalty often shifts from player to player. Items purchased at the village workshop boost the players’ abilities to gather resources, score victory points, rampage, or control areas of the board. Each scientist has his own special abilities which augment game play for that particular player and offer numerous pathways to victory. The first player to 25 victory points wins!


—description from the designer
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Hand Management, Set Collection, Variable Phase Order, Variable Player Powers, Worker Placement

name: Moonstone: Mama's Boys Troupe box
description:
This troupe box includes 3 new heroes of Commonwealth fraction.
This miniatures are made in fine quality resin. Every miniature requires assembly.

Billy and his ram mount are always together. He can attack with extremely high speed and push enemy units away.
Mama Gimble can reduce damage to her if there are any gnome friendly models close to her. Besides she can restore wounds and energy to friendly gnomes.
Quarrel - gnome soldier. He is rather skillful shooter using his crossbow and can support his allied units.

—description from the publisher
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Humor, Miniatures
mechanics: Action Points, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Rock-Paper-Scissors

name: Trudvang Legends: Westmark
description: Trudvang Legends: Westmark is an expansion that opens up an entire new region in the world, covering the mighty and proud Westmark lands. The Westmark expansion introduces not only a whole new campaign with branching stories and multiple endings but also expands the Legends system with a new 2-fold game board with sleeves that integrates seamlessly into the core box's Map board.

name: Moonstone: Gotchgut the Giant Monster Box
description:
This monster box includes one new miniature of giant mercenary. He can be hired either as Dominion or Commonwealth fraction.
This miniature is made in fine quality resin. Miniature requires assembly.
Gotchgut is a giant - very strong, but not so fast being.

—description from the publisher
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Humor, Miniatures
mechanics: Action Points, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Rock-Paper-Scissors

name: Slavisti
description:
Slavisti is an abstract strategy game that comes with matches. It seems very simple at first glance, but is a game with strategic depth. It is designed as a non-commercial game.

Each player has two play areas on the table. In one area, only Roman numbers of 1s (I) 5s (V) and 10s (X) are formed with sticks. In the other area forms are laid. With the exception of the first stick, in the second area, sticks may only be laid at one end of a laying stick. So that both created an angle of 60, 90 or 180 degrees. It usually creates squares and equilateral triangles.
A special feature of the game is that a player can also lay sticks in the opposing areas. If you have laid down a stick in the enemy area, which has an open side, you may only lay there again, if you can lay a stick there, which is then closed at both ends. If that does not work, you can only lay down sticks in your own area.
When all the sticks have been laid, you can only lay sticks; never taking away the last laid wood. In the end, no stick may have an open end.
The goal is to match the number of shapes (rectangles, parallelograms, trapezoids, and triangles) with the number of the Roman numeral.

—description from the publisher

name: Alice
description:
The Ludik Quebec Alice Board Game is a game of observation and speed for children 6 years and older. This game is designed with beautiful illustrations of the characters from the tale of Alice in Wonderland. The first player who finds the identical characters and exhausts all the cards in his deck as soon as possible wins the game! A simple and fun game that will appeal to your youngest!

Getting Ready:

A player shuffles the cards ad separates them into two equal piles
Players sit in front of each other, take their pile of cards and put it face down in front of them
Using the discs they make two columns of four discs each face up, leaving a space between columns large enough to contain four cards side by side.


Playing the game:
The game goes on until one of the players plays out his entire pile of cards.
Each turn is comprised of four steps, each one starting the same way
Players count to three, take the top card of their own pile and put it simultaneously in front of their opponents turned card.
As soon as their cards are turned, players must be quick to locate identical cards. If there are no identical cards on the playing area, players move to the next step.

When there are two identical cards on the playing area, the first player to hit the disc matching the character on them taes a card from his own pile and covers one of the identical cards.
Players move on to the next step only when there are no identical cards on the playing area.

Note: Identical cards may be found in any column, not necessarily facing each other. In that case, players proceed in the same way. The player who is the quickest to hit the right disc covers one of the identical cards using a card from his own pile.

The first player to play the last card on his pile wins the game.

—user summary

name: The Dream-Quest of Unknown Kadath
description:
"Three times I dreamed of the marvellous city..." This game creates the strange and wonderous dream quest of Randolph Carter in H.P. Lovecraft's dream cycle stories, taking its player to terrible and weird worlds to view the dangers within.

A solo game where players gain cards by taking risks. Gained cards may be entered into a tableaux image to complete Dream Quests and so points, or be expended to gain other cards with more difficult requirements. When the game ends players score points for each completed tableaux image, when an image is complete players may then choose to add in further lands and further quests or awaken to whatever comfort they can gain from knowing that they could have delved deeper...

Developed for entry into the 2019 Solitaire Print and Play contest.

—description from the designer
categories: Adventure, Book, Card Game, Exploration, Fantasy, Novel-based, Print & Play
mechanics: Hand Management, Push Your Luck, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Feel me, Feel me Not
description:
Personal space and sexual harassment are hot topics right now.

This game seeks to take the attention away from absolute or objective definitions of what these terms should mean, and focus it on what they do mean to you and to those around you.

A Shared Story

The players get to collaboratively shape their shared reality, as abstractly or as detailed as they want. As a starting point, they use synopses of real stories, that happened to real people.

Know Thyself

“How would I react, if this happened to me? In that story, what would I do?” is what players get to answer first. Practicing introspection, and understanding themselves.

Emphasis on Empathy

Having figured themselves out, players try to understand each other. “I know what I’d do in that situation, but how would that person react if they were in my shoes?”.

Revelations !

Now that everyone has Empathy and Reaction cards, it's time for a show-down - Players' points depend on how well they guessed what others would do!

Ok, but how do I win?

You just need to collect 5 Empathy Points in everyone's color to win a 5-player match - but that also means you have to be able to empathize with everyone on the table! Good luck :)

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Educational, Mature / Adult, Party Game, Print & Play
mechanics: Role Playing, Simultaneous Action Selection, Storytelling

name: The 3rd Heaven
description:
A space exploration and strategy game to find utopia ... the 3rd Heaven.

Amid a dystopian future, disease, corruption, and misery still exist. Four unique characters search for a utopia that will renew the human spirit and set things right for all future peoples.

The 3rd Heaven is a space exploration game where players make strategic choices to upgrade their spaceships with technology that will enable them to find the sacred 3rd Heaven.

For 2-4 players. Games run approximately 45-60 minutes.

Variable player powers, Exploration, Race, Action selection, Modular board, Deck building, Dice rolling, and worker placement.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers, Worker Placement

name: Squadron Strike: Axanar
description:
BASED OFF OF THE AWARD-WINNING FAN FILM “PRELUDE TO AXANAR!”

20 Years before the First Five-Year Voyage, There Was Axanar!

The dawn of a human-led, multispecies civilization was an era of exploration, of seeking out new life and new civilizations. Of boldly going where no one had gone before.

Captains like Garth, Alexander and Travis charted new worlds by the score, leading scientific and diplomatic missions to the edge of explored space. Following the examples of Magellan, Shackleton, and Lewis and Clark, they were scientists and idealists, dedicated to peaceful first contact whenever possible.

It was inevitable that they would run into a hostile power. Under the command of Kharn the Undying, the Empire saw humanity’s peaceful ambitions as a mockery of its own greatness, its constant need to expand to maintain its cultural vitality.

Unprepared for hostile first contact, the human-led explorers and their underarmed fleet soon faced their greatest peril: an invasion orchestrated by a military genius.

Four years of warfare, ending in the Battle of Axanar, shaped everything that followed.

This product requires the Squadron Strike 2e Boxed Set (ADA 1700) to play! If you have a 1st Edition Boxed Set, or only own Attack Vector, pick up the Squadron Strike Upgrade Kit.

—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Action Queue, Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Paper-and-Pencil, Simulation

name: Jurassic Snack: Locomotus Promo Card
description:
A new card that allows you to play with a new rule and a different tiles setup.
New rule: You can use one of your diplodocus as a locomotive. When you move it, all diplodocus behind it move too, just like train cars behind a locomotive.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Animals, Expansion for Base-game

name: Spaceship Redoubt
description:
Spaceship Redoubt (The ship) is a bastion of strength and peace across the united alliance of planets, until a routine patrol of the dangerous border frontier places the ship under attack from vicious shapeshifting pirates! A surprise attack disables the engines, and quickly the pirates board the ship assuming human shape and wearing their uniforms to blend in with the goal of taking over the ship as captain.

Players take on the roles of ship personnel with specific skills, with the intent to discover the hidden pirates, and jail them, repair the engines, and escape. Players may also be a shapeshifting pirate, which means instead they are trying to hide, jail important members of crew, or blow up the engine!

Players have two cards that represent personnel on the ship and can bluff as any of the personnel roles in order to accomplish tasks around the ship, but if they are called out on not having that card, then they can get jailed! You have to balance the risk of failure versus the success of the strength of the task!
Personnel rejoice in victory if all Pirates are jailed, and the engine is repaired. Pirates successfully destroy the ship, by tampering with the engine, or jailing enough personnel so that the ship cannot function!

—description from the designer

name: A Call to Arms Star Fleet: Book Two
description:
A Call to Arms: Star Fleet, Book 2 is the first expansion for the joint venture using Mongoose Publishing’s “A Call to Arms” miniatures system and ADB’s “Star Fleet Universe”.

Set in Amarillo Design Bureau’s Star Fleet Universe, A Call to Arms Star Fleet allows you to command not just a single starship, but an entire squadron of starships. The General War is raging across the Alpha Octant and empire after empire after empire is getting drawn into the conflict. The United Federation of Planets, the Klingon Empire, the Romulan Star Empire, the Gorn Confederacy, the Kzinti Hegemony have been battling it out for supremacy. Now the Thoian Holdfast, the Seltorian Tribunal, and even the Orion Pirates have joined the fray.

From small skirmishes to massive fleet engagements, A Call to Arms Star Fleet puts you in the Captain’s chair for these exciting battles.
ACTASF Book Two includes:
• Full fleet lists for the Tholian Holdfast, the Seltorian Tribunal, and the Pirates of Orion.
• Additional units for the Federation, Klingon, Romulan, Gorn, and Kzinti fleets.
• Battleships, Scouts, and Commando Ships for all fleet lists.
• New rules for Tholian Webs, Seltorian weapons, boarding parties combat, capturing ships, and advanced rules for scouts including electronic warfare.
• A new terrain hazard – The WYN Radiation Zone
• Over 150 detailed ship rosters
• Twenty new scenarios, including 4 versus monsters (The Planet Killer, the Juggernaut, the Morey Eel, and the Sun Snake)

Please note that you must have Book 1.2 to play this game. Book 2 is an expansion.

—description from the publisher
categories: Miniatures, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Altar: the War of Gods – Celts
description:
The story behind Altar: the War of Gods may seem fantastic, strictly imaginary. Mostly, that’s true – but still, there is a wise core in the events around token matches, something interesting to think about.

Powerful creatures, gods from various real-world mythologies feel a lack of humans’ faith. There are not so many people around the globe, who still believe in personalities from ancient legends. That faith is a kind of energy that keeps all those gods alive and supports their might. Getting more faith is the reason for the War of Gods to happen, so it takes place on the game board.
Matches of this game happen on a hexagon board with many small internal hexagons to place playing pieces on.

Three players participate in one battle. The initial step for each of them is a potential sacrifice – players put a token to the central area, an altar. A winner of this match will be able to take all the tokens from the altar or to craft with them a new one.

To play the match, players get from their collections three tokens each. One by one, participants make their turns, placing a token to the entry point. These tokens are various creatures with three different battle actions. Each token can make a specific number of steps on the game board.

There are two ways to win a match in the Altar game:

by clearing the game board from all the other tokens – through battles with them.
by surrounding the central hexagon (the altar) with a specific number of your tokens.

name: Arbiträre Regeln
description:
Arbitrary Rules is a card driven meta-party game which runs passively in the background. The idea of the game is to bring people together in a humorous way. It helps connecting strangers and can function as a social catalyst, be an icebreaker for flirting attempts and makes the players to be attentive about the situations happening around them.

Each player receives an equal amount of cards (depending on how many players will take part) which describes specific but arbitrary rules. After that the game begins.

If a player notices that someone violates one of the rules described on his cards, he plays the card and the player who violated the rule will be sanctioned. After that he passes the card and swaps it with a card of the sanctioned player.

The game has no fixed ending, it ends arbitrarily!

The player who plays the most cards during the game will win. To count the amount of cards which each player plays, tokens such as coins or bottle caps are used.

name: BITE
description:
As the harvest approaches, the villagers gather and ponder the coming winter. Among them, darkness lurks, corrupting the town and its inhabitants. Unlikely allies will rise to either save this village or condemn it.

Can you make it through the lengthening nights and save the town? Or is something creeping up on you, disguised as a neighbor, waiting for its chance to BITE?

BITE is a social deduction game with secret roles for social gatherings. Players receive roles and pair up for a few minutes of conversation at a time, at the end of which each reveals an action card to the other player. They resolve these cards and move on to the next discussion, their motives changing throughout the game based upon which side they find themselves: Good or Evil. By the final night, either darkness will have been rooted out of the town, or it will have triumphed.

Each role has action cards associated with it that reveal information about their conversation partner, protect them from harm, convert them to their side, or kill them off in various ways. The roles are themed to a gothic fantasy setting including Witches, Hunters, Villagers, Occultists, Vampires and the like.

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game, Deduction, Horror, Party Game
mechanics: Hidden Roles, Role Playing, Team-Based Game, Traitor Game, Variable Player Powers

name: Pontiac's War: Frontier Rebellion, 1763-66
description:
“I mean to destroy the English and leave not one upon our lands.” Pontiac
“It is not in the Indian’s power to affect anything of consequence.” Major Gladwin.”

Pontiac’s War 1763-1766 followed on the heels of the French and Indian War which ended in 1763. Thanks to Indian resentment over the French surrender of their lands and the harsh policies of General Jeffery Amherst, governor-general of British North America, 20+ Indian nations rose up under the charismatic leadership of the Ottawa sachem, Pontiac and the Lenape Holy Man, Neolin. When the powder-smoke cleared, 450 British soldiers and countless Indians had lost their lives. Two thousand settlers were either killed or captured and 4000 more had been displaced. Moreover, Britain’s foreign conflicts had put the Crown 140 million £ in debt. These expenses led directly to a series of unpopular taxes in North America which in turn led directly to another uprising, our colonial revolution.

Pontiac’s War attempts to recreate the reaction of Indian leaders to British mishandling of frontier politics and the impending colonial crisis it presaged. Building on the point-to-point system and loose Indian alliances used in King Philip’s War and Blood on the Ohio, this design expands frontier conflict using Battle cards to introduce combat chaos, British expenditure on troops, Uncertain Indian Armssupply, siege rules, the capture of prisoners, French interference and trader influence.

The game offers five short introductory scenarios (15-30 minutes), three one-year campaign scenarios (2 hours), and one three-year grand campaign (5-6 hours). Although not a solitaire design, it is solitaire friendly. Players will appreciate the high-production quality of the components which includes a MOUNTED game map and large, 338 3/4" size punch-out counters.

Product Information:

Complexity: 4 out of 10
Solitaire Suitability: 5 out of 10
Time Scale: Seasonal turns (approx. 3 months per turn)
Map Scale: Point-to-Point map (approx. 60-75 miles between points)
Unit Scale: 30-50 men, 4-6 artillery guns, individual officers and sea vessels
Players: 1 or 2 (best with 2)
Playing Time: from 15 minutes (intro scenarios) to 6 hours (grand campaign)

—description from the publisher
categories: Age of Reason, American Indian Wars, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Movement Points, Point to Point Movement, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Simulation

name: Killjoy: Pocket Play
description:
Killjoy: Pocket Play is the anti-party game. This 52-card game is an action-packed good time for 2-4 players.

Jerry is the guy from work who throws the worst parties. When you tell him you can't go, he starts asking questions.

Your goal is to be the first player to escape Jerry's party by answering all 3 of his questions with appropriate excuses.

But, move quickly! Your friends don't plan on going either, and they might notice you experiencing things like a Panic Attack or Sweaty Palms.

The first player to escape 3 parties will be crowned the ultimate killjoy.

Great for non-gamers, new gamers, light gamers, and anyone wanting a quick fun round!

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game, Humor, Party Game, Print & Play

name: MUSA
description:
Color matching hexagonal card game. Deck consists of sixty cards.

The hexagonal cards are divided into six colors per card out of a possible nine colors.

GAME PLAY


2 to 4 players are dealt 7 cards each,
5 to 7 players are dealt 5 cards each.


Players take turns dealing, person to the left of the dealer goes first. Game starts by player one laying a card face up on the table and drawing a card from the deck. Player two tries to match color to color, then, the next player and so on, the winner is the first one to play all their cards, white wedge is a wild color, black wedge blocks any match. If a player matches.


ONE color you draw a card and your turn ends
TWO colors, you don’t draw a card and your turn ends
THREE colors, you don’t draw a card and you get to take another turn
FOUR colors, you give a player of choice one of your care and you get to take another turn
FIVE colors and you automatically win the game
(SIX colors and you win this and the next six games, there is no need to play them.)

name: The Snitch: Prison Showers
description:
This is a small expansion for The Snitch.

After completing a scheme, you don't just put the scheme card aside, you have to place it on the Prison Showers card. Depending on where you place the card, you complete a specific mission that gives you a benefit or penalty. When completing the final scheme, you also find one bullet for your gun. You'll need it if you want to wound the snitch, so he can't ruin your escape attempt.

The expansion has two sides:

side A: This side is perfect for beginners because it makes the escape easier. New players still have to learn the game and make more mistakes, so it's easier for the snitch to win. By using side A, you compensate for this lack of experience.

side B: This side is only for experienced players who find it quite easy to escape. Side B makes the escape more difficult. Good news for the snitch!

-description from publisher
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Negotiation, Party Game

name: Ambush at Rannungen:  A 1985 MBT Scenario
description:
NOTE: This game is no longer for sale.

***All briefings and maps can be downloaded from the files section of this page for free. The maps should be printed on 12 x 18 inch paper to produce an 11 x 17 inch map.***

Ambush at Rannugen depicts a never fought 1985 engagement in the Fulda Gap using Jim Day's and GMT’s MBT Game pitting a reinforced US tank company team of the 1st Infantry Division (Forward) against a reinforced Warsaw Pact Motorized Rifle Battalion in Germany.

The scenario reflects my experience as a Company Commander in 1984-1985 The game explores a way to use terrain in a different manner to defeat the enemy. In a conventional defense, the US establishes a killing zone by positioning on good terrain with frontal and flank shots to destroy the enemy once he enters the zone. Here, the tactic is to position the US force in such a manner that he is rewarded with shots on the enemy's rear and flanks while at the same time perhaps avoiding some of the enemy's artillery bombardment. The dicey part, however, is withdrawing and getting to a new position after finishing the engagement.

Like other scenarios I have released, it is not balanced although players may balance it as they deem fit.

To play the game, you must have a copy of the initial GMT MBT Game. The expansion includes 4 11 x 17 maps scaled at 100 meters per hex (the same scale as the MBT game), a Scenario Briefing, a US Battle Book and a Soviet Battle book with deployment instructions and order of battle listing, and a terrain key. The map is based on a period map of the battle area and utilizes contours to depict elevation.

Expansion sets are not required (BAOR, FRG, and the forthcoming Canadian supplement) provide additional vehicle counters as well as leaders. A list of substitute counters is provided to enable the player to field the complete order of battle for both sides or the players can use some of the expansion set vehicles or combine sets to complete the order of battle.

Rannugen can be played with two players but may be more interesting if played with up to 4 players on the US side (CO and the five platoon leaders), and 5 on the USSR side (Battalion Commander and 4 company commanders), and a referee.

—description from the designer

name: Villages: Friends Promo Card
description:
Friends
Light Unit
When you give this unit to another player during your give phase. You can move a card from your graveyard to the discard pile.

Given out at SaltCon End of Summer 2019.
categories: Card Game, Civilization, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy
mechanics: Hand Management, Set Collection, Variable Player Powers

name: Catakombes Dark Reign
description:
Become a legendary hero, rich and powerful. Arm yourself with bravery and challenge the evil creatures! Lovely promises of fortune and glory will bring you to deep forgotten catacombs, but only a true hero, with a body and mind forged in the strongest steel will survive.

Half role playing game, half figurine (1:50 scale) Catakombes Dark Reign is a cooperative game for 1 to 3 players embodying a group of heroes, who form an alliance against their opponents to accomplish their quest, while another player gives life to the adventure as the game master. The game takes place in an alternative medieval era, where legendary creatures and magic coexist with the real world.

Purpose of the game
Incarnate a hero willing to over- come every risk to achieve the main quest.
1/Setting up
You need to define who the heroes (PC) are and who the Game Master (GM) is. We recommend a group of three adventurers PCs. The game master (GM) is in charge of animating the adventure for the PCs in the respect of the game’s rules.
The GM chooses a quest and prepares the « Catacombs’ plan » cards enables to create a unique gaming board for each game.
Each PC chooses a character with the help of a predefined sheet or PCs create their own character if they wish.
The introduction of the game takes place in a narrative way. The GM describes the quest to the PCs, who verbally describe their actions. Every conceivable actions are possible, it is up to the GM to adapt them to the game.
When PCs enter the catacombs the game play is in turns.
2/Game turn
During a game turn, there is first the PCs’ turn then the GM’s turn and each turn is divided into 3 phases.
PC’s turn :
Phase 1: The characters recover all their action points (A.Point).
Phase 2: One of the PC’s (by turns) draw an unexpected card at the start of each turn (except in the first turn of the game) and the PCs suffer its effects. Take care of all the various effects affecting the PCs and their allies (Fear, Burning, Poisoned...), and remove expired markers.
Phase 3: Each PC does his actions (walk, run, attack, search ...). Each time a PC does an action, he removes the equivalent action points as indicated by the action’s cost. When a character is activated, they aren’t obligated to spend all their action points in one go. For example, they may do one action then let another PC or ally play their actions and finish their actions afterwards. But once the PC’s turn is over, all remaining action points are lost.
GM’s Turn:
The GM repeats the 3 phases of a turn, like during the PCs’ turn (bare in mind that the GM doesn’t draw an unexpected event card). The GM’s characters play in the GM’s desired order.
3/End of the game
The game ends when the main quest is completed or all PCs are eliminated.
The GM then reads the conclusion of the quest and the PCs intervene verbally describe their actions.
The PCs add up the experience points, Ecus earned and the treasures found during the game and share them equally.
Then the PCs spend their experience points to develop their characteristics and gain new skills. They can go to town in order to buy new equipment with their hard-earned ecus.

- description from publisher

name: Hatching Dragons
description:
Hatching Dragons is a fun worker placement and card drafting game.

With the popularity of Dungeon crawlers at an all time high, Dungeon Masters are constantly in need of more dragons. This is where you come in.

2 players compete to hatch a collection of coloured dragons that you sell to Dungeon Masters to earn bags of gold.

By selecting eggs, matching crystals, and raising the temperature so that conditions are right, you will earn gold for each dragon you can hatch. You can also complete special orders of dragon combinations to earn even more.
The winner is the player with the most gold at the end of the game.

—description from the designer

name: Flick Wars
description:
Flick Wars is a strategy and tactics dexterity game with six factions that range from humans to mechs to alien races. Each faction has a unique set of units.

This is a listing for the 2 player print and play version that was temporarily posted to the kickstarter for the game.

name: Forest Fire!: A Family Game
description:
Available from TheGameCrafter at https://thegamecrafter.com/games/forest-fire-?
The rules are available online at https://www.ideategames.org/forestfire/forestfire_rules.pdf

Forest Fire! was inspired by a little boy who loves fighting fires. The game is set in a densely wooded yet populated area where forest fires often occur. When fires start, players work together to put them out and save houses and schools from destruction.

Players use several fire fighting approaches – bulldozers, water, helicopters and chemical extinguishers. Fires occur randomly (FOREST FIRE cards) and spread every turn. Wind changes direction and intensity frequently, affecting the spread of the fires. Players contain the fires with bulldozer firebreaks and throw water and fire extinguisher balls (fire retardant) on the fires by hand or from a helicopter.

As the game progresses, environmental factors like wind and drought increase, affecting the frequency, intensity, and spreading speed of fires, simulating the effects of climate change.

We noted the other game of the same name and same setting, but the play mechanics are very different. This is not a strategy game, but a fairly simple but exciting family game.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Grid Movement, Worker Placement

name: Arcane Blaster Casters
description:
Arcane Blaster Casters is a frantic arena fighting game for 2-8 spellcasters. Players take on the roles of magic users as they embark on an all-out mystical battle for arcane dominance or simply petty vengeance.

Each turn, the players will use their hand of cards to cast a spell. A spell will usually be created from three cards (elements) in their hand, and placed face down ready for the casting phase. Players will have to act fast however as the quicker a player prepares their spell, the earlier they'll be able to cast it and inflict pain upon their opponents.

Once all casters have prepared their spells, they begin the process of flinging them at each other: In order of initiative, each player places a missile token on their caster then moves it around the arena, then deals damage and other harmful statuses to the target(s) depending on the spell's effects.

Casters that end up on the wrong side of a fireball need not fear, for death is merely an inconvenience! When their physical forms expire, casters explode in a burst of magical energy and become sentient slimes. In this form players cannot win the game, but killing a living caster will return them to life, allowing players a chance to snatch victory once more.

The game is won by the last caster to be left alive, so don your finest robes and hats and prepare your toughest spells... You'll need every advantage you can get to be the last Arcane Blaster Caster!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Grid Movement, Square Grid, Take That

name: True Frenemies
description:
A Christian, busy family, party board game of good friends, bad friends, and very bad friends. In True Frenemies you will need to bring not only yourself but also another player, whom we will call your Secret Friend, to the Tree of Life. The catch? You will know your own Secret Friend, but you will have no idea who has you as a Secret Friend. Get ready to enter a mixed-up world where your friends may suddenly turn on you and your worst enemy saves the day. Success in this game requires deception, cooperation, as well as acts of assistance alongside betrayal.

—description from the designer
categories: Abstract Strategy, Bluffing, Educational, Memory, Religious
mechanics: Acting, Hidden Roles, Lose a Turn, Memory, Prisoner's Dilemma, Roll / Spin and Move, Take That

name: Crazy Unicorns
description:
